reviewText:
"Frozen Ground" is a film based on the events leading up to the arrest of serial killer, Robert Hansen, who was convicted of killing four women, but is known to have killed over twenty.  Some of the best crime thrillers are those that keep the tension mounting and don't detract from the story.  "Silence of the Lambs" and "Seven" are still, to my mind, two of the best crime thrillers ever done.  "Frozen Ground" for the most part, fulfills these two requirements.  It is a solid entry of the genre that won't disappoint.

Cindy Paulson (played very well by Vanessa Hudgens) is a local prostitute who has just escaped certain death at the hands of Robert Hansen.  She is found trembling in a room by police.  However, Hansen appears to have a solid alibi for his whereabouts, and due to Paulson's questionable job and character, her story is not taken as credible by the D.A.  The irony is that Paulson is the only known person to have escaped from Hansen, and yet her story is, at least initially, not believed.

Enter Alaskan State Trooper, Jack Halcombe who is asked to investigate the matter.  Halcombe is based on Glenn Flothe, the actual  Alaskan State Trooper who had been investigating the discovery of several bodies of women dumped in the Alaskan wilderness.  At first, Halcombe is reluctant to investigate a case, that he feels, should be the responsibility of the local law enforcement.  However, the deeper he looks, the more convinced he becomes that Paulson is telling a credible story and that Hansen is the man responsible.

Robert Hansen is a man who appears to be anything but a serial killer (yes, we've heard the profile by many law enforcement officials about how serial killers don't have a particular look).  He runs a bakery and has a wife and two children.  He has many friends, and he is even acquainted with some of the people of the Anchorage Police Department, who mostly swear that Hansen is a stand-up citizen who can't possibly be the serial killer that Halcombe is looking for.

The strength of the film is in the journey, not the destination.  This isn't a film about who is doing the killing.  We all know.  It's about how Halcombe is able to finally present a solid case against Hansen.  The story takes place in the early 80s when the acquiring of forensic evidence isn't like what we see today.  Halcombe is also angry with the D.A. for not providing him with a warrant to search Hansen's property.  The D.A. argues that Halcombe has no evidence or basis for him to get a warrant.  Meanwhile, Paulson is still out there, and just how long can she survive?  Halcombe has to find evidence against Hansen and also find a way to protect Paulson, a known rebellious prostitute who is also a drug addict.

The strength of the film rests with its two principle actors: John Cusack and Nicholas Cage.  This is some of the best work I've seen in years from Cage.  It reminded me of how good he can be when he chooses smart roles to play.  Cusack, who is good in just about everything he does, is exceptional as Robert Hansen.  We get a brief glimpse into the mind of Hansen and what drove him to prey on all of these women.

An element that prevents this film from being even better is too much focus on Paulson.  We know that she is a key element for Halcombe, but too much time spent on her drug addiction and trying to get money by becoming a stripper takes away from the film rather than adding to it.  I would have rather had more time spent on Hansen.  His character is the most interesting.  Also 50 Cent(who plays Paulson's pimp) needs to keep away from acting.  It's not his forte at all.

All in all, you can't go wrong with this film.  If you like crime thrillers as much as I do, then this will be a welcome addition for you.

This film is based on the true story of a serial killer named Robert Hansen. The story is basically about how a cop works tirelessly to bring him to justice.

Lately, I have not been expecting Nicholas Cage films to be good.  In fact, I go in with very low expectations.  Seeing he was going to star in this movie with Vanessa Hudgens, that just lowered them even more.

Then I saw the film.  I was surprised that it was as good as it was.  It is less than an hour and fifty minutes, so the movie moves at a pretty decent pace.  Hudgens actually surprised me.  She did a pretty good job.  She was very convincing as a prostitute.

Cage's performance was not that different from other movies.  He has played a cop very often and did a very good job here.  What made this film work is mainly the chemistry between the actors.

John Cusack plays Robert Hansen.  That is not a spoiler by the way.  You know he is the one early on.  It is not a mystery genre film.  It is a true crime film.  I think he played Hensen well.  Hensen was known as a nerdy guy and I think Cusack captured that.

Overall, I give the film five stars.  I like true crime films and books.  If you do as well, this movie should keep you interested throughout your viewing.

I've read a book about this case -- "Hunted on Ice" -- a book that I didn't recommend, and left a review on this site as to why.  I also have seen a couple of documentaries as well, documentaries that made me initially interested in this case.  So I was really interested in seeing this film, particularly since John Cusack is one of the stars, and I've always been a big fan of his.  As I always say, if you disagree with me, just check out "High Fidelity" or "Grosse Pointe Blank."

But suffice it to say, after just watching today on pay-per-view, I am fairly disappointed in the final product.  In my opinion, they spent way too much film footage (or make that digital storage nowadays) in strip bars here (some people may say that as a plus, I suppose), and too much time dealing with the Cindy Paulson character.  Yes, she was an instrumental witness that ultimately helped convict Robert Hansen, as she was one of the only women he intended to kill who didn't die by his hands.  Or make that more by his gun.  I just don't feel that I really got to know or understand the Hansen character here much because the time that she spent on the screen was time lost for Mr. Cusack.

But still, if I were to stack rank the acting performances in this film, I would rank them as follows (best to worst):  Vanessa Hudgens, Nicholas Cage, and then finally Mr. Cusack.  But I'm not exactly sure that this was Mr. Cusack's fault; I'm not convinced that the screenplay gave him enough time on screen.  But at the same time, I think that he may have been slightly miscast as well; in reality, I believe that his talents were wasted on this surprisingly minimalist role.  And Mr. Hansen has a stutter in real life, and I think that that's always difficult for most actors to pull off on screen.

But perhaps the biggest disappointment for me:  I believe that they changed quite a bit of the true story for dramatic effect.  During the real search of the house, from what I remember, they found quite a few actual trophies from the victims.  Here, they seemed to allude that he buried them remotely under a fallen tree.  And there is a scene that shows the Hansen character paying someone to "off" Ms. Paulson.  Now, I can't believe that Mr. Hansen would ever pay anyone to kill anyone for him; he seemed to be pretty good at it himself.  And there is a subsequent scene where Ms. Hudgens almost dies by this paid assassin's hands and gets away.  (I may be wrong, but I don't think that any of this happened in the real case, from what I've read and seen.)

I've always said, "When you've got a good story, just tell it."  And I think that this unfortunately happened to a film that should have been incredibly riveting.  I'll give a minor recommendation to those familiar with the case; otherwise, I'll give an unfortunate pass.

Closely based on the real serial killer Robert Hansen this is not an action film but a suspence thriller. Thought provoking it tells the stroy very well and down to small details. Cage is unusual in the role of Jack Halcombe (a character based on the case's detective Glenn Flothe) as a tired detective that starts to puzzle the pieces together in a much larger puzzle than he suspects at the start. Many of the victims (but not all) were prostitutes that no one missed or really cared for. In the rare occasion that they did escape who would take their word against a respectable family man. Cusack's preformance as Robert Hansen is very good. Not the evil in flesh like Hannibal Lecter, he is very evil in his own right and you get to see his real evil behind the front he presents to the world and even a glimpse of terror his wife is forced to live with.

So don't buy this expecting an Cage action flick or Seven. But rather a well told story of real crime.
Excellent movie. Love true stories. Nicholas Cage did a wonderful job as usual.
excellent movie .....
It was pretty good.
Excellent acting by all actors. Definitely worth the watch and as good as acclaimed movies like: Zodiac.

Great recreation of justice finally served. This is one of the better performances of Nicholas Cage. I don't really care for Nicholas because most of his performances are exceedingly dull and monotonous with very little change in emotional expression and delivered in a very monotone voice, but in this performance, he actually showed some feeling of emotions.
pretty good
exciting
Another shaky camera pile of crap. Well done Mr. Cage. Only you can make so many turd piles in such a short time.

One of Nicholas Cage's better movies.  John Cusack is excellent as the serial killer.  The cinematography
is excellent.  The writing, direction and editing are crisp.  Well executed movie.

My Wife and I really enjoy the access we get thru our Amazon Prime subscription to films that in many instances we have never heard of before. The Frozen Ground is one of those films that even if you do not have a Prime subscription, you should consider renting.

We both like Nick Cage and were pleased to learn that he was the lead in this film - we had never heard of it before and despite always priding ourselves on keeping up with what is going on in the news, we had never heard or read about this serial murder spree or it's conclusion.  Nick Cage gives a great performance, as do the other actors but it was really good to see Nick in a film and role that is worthy of his talent!

This film is a thriller from start to finish and one that will keep you guessing just how they are going to catch this killer. Definitely recommended.

THANK YOU, AND GOD BLESS ALL WHO FIGHT FOR TRUTH AND JUSTICE.
AS A SURVIVOR, THIS MOVIE IS NOT JUST A GREAT MOVIE WITH GREAT ACTORS, IT IS COMFORTING, IN THIS VERY, VERY UGLY WORLD, TO SEE THERE ARE SOME PEOPLE WHO TRULY CARE ABOUT VICTIMS OF SUCH CRIMES!
MAY WE ALL FIND SAFTY AND PEACE SOME DAY.
THANK YOU, CINDY!!!!
THANK YOU!!!
Very good story telling of a mass murder who finally got what he deserved.  Important to tell the victims story.  Great acting.
must watch

This is one of those "based on a true story" movies. Unfortunately that is the same vein as reality TV; more TV than reality. That is the case with this movie. There is quite a bit of the Hollywood wrapper around this story. Nevertheless it is well procedure. It tells the story. The viewer  is drawn into the story. Nicholas Cage does an excellent job acting. What harms the movie is resolving the crime that took place over years (perhaps 10) and being resolved in 105 minutes. There is no way to compress a timeline that much without compromising the story somewhat.
A serial killer police procedural with Cage. What's there not to like ?
kept my attention the entire movie!

Cage is known for his over-the-top cheesy and/or action movies but I still watch and enjoy them. This, on the other hand, was not his typical movie. I think partially because it's based on a true story and the normal wackiness was reigned in. It reminded me that he really is a great actor. Also nice to see Vanessa Hudgens in a gritty role and getting away from her squeaky clean image. *spoiler* So glad that no-one came after his wife and kid. That's so redundant in so many movies.
That being said...my only 2 problems with this movie was that my mind was constantly trying to figure out the time period that it happened (maybe it was in the beginning and I missed it). The cars/clothes were 70's and 80's but they were talking about semen (testing wasn't used in court until 1986) and other samples and she had a cell phone (car phone) which really didn't start to become massively used until the late 80's (for the rich/city-bound) and early 90's. I couldn't imagine that they had reliable use in Alaska during that time (my friend lives in Juniper and still has a hard time getting a good signal)...especially driving the distance she did during a snow storm. I do like that they included FBI profiling because it really wasn't acknowledged as legitimate yet during those years. Overall...I thoroughly enjoyed the movie. I thought the images of the victims at the end was a kind acknowledgement by the producers. Well done.
A note to anyone interested: He died of natural causes in 2016. Rothschild, the assistant district attorney said "He will not be missed, Good riddance to him. He's one of those kind of guys that you kind of hope every breath he takes in his life, there's some pain associated with it, because he caused such pain."
Beyond excellent.  Stellar cast knock it out of the park.  Remember to story,...WOW!  B-)

Better than I expected.  I have avoided Nicholas Cage movies for the past decade or so since he is usually in bad movies, but this is a good one.  There were a couple of inconsistencies and plot points which were jarring or annoying, but I was able to ignore them to focus on the story.
This was a suspenseful and generally well told story, that kept me on the edge of my seat.  And knowing it was based on a true story made me that much more invested.  A solid movie.

I had never heard of this movie, but saw it listed on my FireTablet and decided to give it a try. It's pretty gripping - well acted by Cage and Cusack, as well as the lead actress whom I had never seen before. Part of its appeal, and its problem, is that it's based on real-life events. I found it a lot more disturbing and depressing knowing that it really happened - not in a good way. But overall - it was worth watching and learning about the hunt for a horrible serial killer that I had never heard about before...

This is one of the older movies that I had been wanting to see. Mainly because I like Nicholas Cage and John Cusack. Both can play just about any role and both proved it on this one. Nicholas Cage is a detective in Alaska following leads to a possible serial killer but his killing ground is in the mountains and wooded areas of Alaska so finding any connection to bodies, some never located is extremely hard. Like I mentioned it is an old movie and based on true events and had it been a big budget movie it would have been an even greater movie. It is worth seeing if only to watch two great actors trying to outwit each other.
Stupid good, raw, real, and one everyone should watch if your a Cage/Cusak fan.

Superb in its craftsmanship by each and every individual, group, team and entity involved. The best out of all talents and makers of movies worldwide, that I have seen, in over twentyfive years. And without a doubt the best that Ms. Hudgens and Mr. Cage have ever done. I say five stars is not enough when deserving a googleplex.
great movie!

Really enjoy a movie that keeps you interested from start to finish. I would have liked to have had a little more back round into the killers childhood and what made him a monster. I felt sympathy for the victims, but not enough hate for the killer.

Saw the listing in Prime and thought why not.  Cage is usually in interesting flicks.  The storyline intrigued me as I didn't recall ever hearing about this crime and wondered what it was about.  Enjoyed some of the reviews from folks who lived through the period and shared the fact the film took time to reflect the story as accurately as possible.  Also appreciated the fact they honored the victims throughout the movie.  Very impactful viewing experience.  Makes us realize how vulnerable we all are.
This film is recycled, derivative, contrived garbage.
John Cusack did an amazing job of portraying the worst possible aspects of man. Cage and Cusack had great chemistry and they made the movie

This is the kind of crap coming out of Hollywood that has contributed to an America full of violence.  School shootings, police brutality, random killings come from impressionable minds that have grown up watching this sort of crud.
Good movie.
This is a good movie to watch.  John Cusack and Nicolas Cage do a fantastic job.  It's unfortunate it was based on true events.....sad so many women died before Hansen was caught.
Excellent cast for this true story!

Well acted. Better use of outdoor/indoor contrast would have added variety in the backgrounds scenes, and reinforced the contrast of bondage and freedom and death and life. The moose cameo was fortuitous. So was 50 Cents appearance. Cuts between scenes could have been clearer. The wife's change of heart was specious. But I liked it! Good movie, with a few technical issues in the story lines and scenes worthy of polishing.

Cage really does shine in this film. He was a great cast selection here and gives just enough to the character without overdoing it. Vanessa Hudgens deserves hardware for her role. Honestly one of the better dramatic performances in recent memory. She is as believable as it gets being cast in a very difficult role. No one likes to credit the bad guy, but Cusack does what he is paid to do quite effectively here. Supporting cast has no weak links IMO. The story moves at a brisk pace, not getting hung up anywhere too long along the way. A pretty easy 5-stars.
What a good movie. I enjoyed every second of it, had me on the edge of  my seat two thumbs up.

Much better than I expected based on reviews.... Yes, there were a few twee moments... but it's sort of like going to a good restaurant and liking everything you have except the stuffed mushrooms... yes, some moments were cliched, but the movie as a whole is engaging, and the story it tells is compelling... and the acting by Nicholas Cage, Vanessa Hudgens, and John Cusack are quite worth watching... And the story is both exciting and heartrending.
great actors; especially Nicholas Cage;  but what happened to the "thug"?  did I miss something?
Pretty well rounded movie.  Not the best I have seen but definitely worth the watch.
Great Movie, good actors!
great acting, I agree with someone else that cinematography could have been better, but loved it regardless. Good re-watch.  Vanessa Hudgins was impressive.

John Cusack is terrifying as Hansen and Nicholas Cage is perfect as a moral, tenacious detective. But Vanessa Hudgens steals the show with her gut-wrenching performance. Affecting and upsetting, but a story worth telling.
2.35/5.1  This movie is quite an adventure. There is some shooting. There is violence. There is plenty of snow. This is mostly an investigation. This is a true story.
This was definitely one of the best movies Ive seen on Prime in a while and the best performances Ive seen by Cage, Cusak & Hudgens.

I really like Nicholas Cage and John Cusak. Powerful acting to portray a story from real life. I question the how Cindy could get so dumb after reading Hansen so accurately in the beginning especially after being so heart-stopping scared. I figure that's Hollywood for you--the real story has to be jazzed up to make it "better." Not. However, desperation makes a person do some stupid things, and Cindy was desperate.

Since it was Nicholas Cage, I knew it would have a lot of F-bombs, and it did. I wasn't prepared for the nudity and torture though. I fast forwarded through all that and didn't miss a thing.

The movie was good. Not something I'd watch again.
Incredible!  It's really good.

Interesting story, good casting; John Cusack gave a realistic portrayal of the serial; and Cage of the detective; and actress who played Cindy was great.  Important topic to be shown even is it is hard to watch.

Good true  detective story about a serial killer in Alaska. I am most impressed with the reviews of people who were there during the hunt. Most said the movie was accurate and authentic of the events. Considering some true story movies these days, that is high praise and enough for five stars. This is one of Nicholas Cage's best movies in recent years.

This film could've been a lot better with tighter direction, more editing. Most of the secondary characters were too one-dimensional. Nicolas Cage was great but Vanessa Hudgens was completely miscast. She didn't have it in her to portray a hard-bitten, drug-addicted prostitute. It got pretty frustrating watching such an overacted performance. Unfortunately, a good amount of the film revolves around her story line.

Good movie.
The right ending.

This was a really good movie! Didn't know that all this was taking place during that timeframe because I was just a little kid. I'm glad the authorities were able to capture the killer and put him away. It was very sad that he "hunted" the hookers.....these girls are already down on their self-esteem (obviously do the work that they do)....All around this movie was heart-breaking knowing what these girls went through. I wonder what this killers actual kids must think of their father?? hmmm #POS ?
Excellent movie!

This was a very haunting movie. And it was real. Applause to the detective who first refused to let the information be brushed off and filed away - he started the whole undoing of this tragic tale. All of the performances large and small were open and honest and true to living in those spaces and perspectives. I don't understand people and their dislike of Ms. Hudgen's portrayal of Cindy; because I thought she showed a woman who had lived through too much for too long and the result was her own sense of balance that couldn't quite keep her upright emotionally nor in spirit.  But was someone who desperately wanted to believe that there could be a better life ahead.  I have not seen her in other roles though I did recognize her. Maybe at the time people who followed her career felt it was a  forced choice and a departure - but even so she was incredibly adept at playing a vulnerable person who lived in and out of cause and effect. I was moved by the character's story.  I only know at the end of the movie it hit me like a pressurized wave of sorrow:  that this really happened to so many young women and how brutal and awful and terrifying it must have been, my heart just breaks for them all.  And I was very proud of that fact that Cindy was able to survived it all and walked away to have a life that triumphed over that bastard's intent to destroy it. I LOVE that this woman is still with us living a beautiful life.

Very Good film.  Drama & Mystery combined.  I didn't appreciate the choice for the main actress. With regards to the screenplay: for  someone (the female character) who showed a bit of smarts at beginning of her situation, she certainly was an overall looser for the most part.  True story.  I'd watch it again at a later date.
Fantastic movie with awesome actors.  So many killed, so few found.....watch this...
Remarkable true story that has one good ending and many sad ones...
Awesome movie, Both amazing and sad,
horribly slow
First thought dark and depressing, but finding out it's a true story it's very well done. they could have shown much worse, but thank heavens they didn't. they show enough for you to understand .
I love the movie it was very very good haven't seen a good movie in a long time.!!!!

So hard to find a really good movie today, but this one is a winner.  Cusack and Cage are perfectly casted for their roles in this thrilling true story filmed in Anchorage, Alaska.  Well worth the watch!

I really liked this movie the first time I saw it, but on second viewing, its weaknesses became apparent. The good Nicholas Cage showed up this time and John Cusack is great as oddball family man/serial killer Robert Hansen. But Vanessa Hudgens, using the film to say "I'm grown up now!," plays a hooker like she's in a high school play missing only the gum smacking and short skirt (the film takes place in Alaska). Part of the problem is the script which turns Hudgen's Cindy Paulson into a flighty, annoying plot device. At a certain point I was rooting for her to get taken out. Also, Hudgens seems to be the only nude dancer in the world who doesn't actually dance nude. Memories of Flashdance. The true story of Robert Hansen, the "Butcher Baker," is actually more horrific than depicted in the film.
very good
One out of many of my favorite films and the shipping went by fine. The movie is in great condition. Love the story to this film.
oh my goodness this movie is good! the suspense will have you sitting on the edge of your seat. John Cusack played such a believing role.
Great acting, strong presentation of a disturbed mind and the convoluted trail to unravel it.
exciting  and fine performance by all
Two actors you don't expect to play these roles did it on extending job especially Nicolas Cage one of my favorite suspense drama it's a must-watch
Plot is OK. Acting is just ok.
Loved it Thank you

RELEASED IN 2013 and written & directed by Scott Walker, "The Frozen Ground" is a crime thriller based on the true story of Alaskan serial killer Robert Hansen, who raped, tortured and killed numerous young women from 1971-1983. Vanessa Hudgens plays a 17 year-old prostitute who successfully escaped from Hansen (John Cusack). Nicolas Cage plays the trooper who establishes a relationship with her as he zeroes-in on Hansen.

This has elements like Kiss the Girls (1997), The Flock (2007) and Hardcore (1979). If you like those crime thrillers, youll appreciate this one. The Anchorage locations are perpetually overcast, but breathtaking and foreboding. Cusack is notable as the average-looking killer and Cage is stalwart as usual. The events take place in 1983 when anchorage was booming due to the pipeline and the ensuing sex industry. The scenes depicting the sleazy underbelly of the city (at that time) are well done and convincing.

THE MOVIE RUNS 1 hour 45 minutes and was shot entirely in Alaska.

GRADE: B
I enjoyed this movie and it was suspenseful.  I really like Nicholas Cage also he is one of my favorite actors.

Scott Walker, in his directorial debut kept pace, story and performances strong.  Since the story is true.  I wanna see his next film.

Bought as a gift.  Feedback is so so. Drug and human trafficking  turns out a detective chasing a serial killer of more than 20 women,  These women are kidnapped, chained, drugged and killed in a Canadian snow-covered forest.  No evidence.  No witness.  This evil killer suspect is
calm and free from law enforcement.  Until one surviving dancer stands out as a witness, the detective can close these cold cases.
John Cusack gives a helluva performance, while Nicolas Coppela rises to a decent pedestrian portrayal (the best he can muster), but the prostitute bimbo is obnoxious in this predictable screenplay.

Excellent performances from John Cusack as the mousy real life serial killer Robert Hansen, Nic Cage as the intrepid detective hot on his trail, and Vanessa Hudgens as the plucky almost-victim who gets away from him can't quite overcome the often clunky, cliche-riddled script and overbearing score that rises up any time any of the characters do so much as walk across a room. It's not easy to make a great movie of a serial killer story (Silence of the Lambs is probably the only one I can think of off hand) and Frozen Ground tries and on a few levels succeeds - watch for the scene were Cusack, being interrogated, makes his jaw twitch from nervousness. There are the usual plot contrivances that defy belief - such as when Cusack's almost-victim, Hudgens, walks into the interrogation room, stares at him for a few moments, and he confesses all.... erm, yeah. In real life, Hansen confessed when presented with a map he'd made pinpointing his victims' bodies - but I guess that wasn't dramatic enough. Then there are the scenes between Cage and his wife, which read like a bad Lifetime TV movie. Still, not a bad effort. It goes to show you how difficult making a good film can be, and how only one or two substandard elements can throw the whole thing into the B-fare category....
Great film. Even more so since it was based on a true story.

I had never heard of this movie, but saw it listed on my FireTV and decided to give it a try.  It's pretty gripping - well acted by Cage and Cusack, as well as the lead actress whom I had never seen before.  Part of its appeal, and its problem, is that it's based on real-life events.  I found it a lot more disturbing and depressing knowing that it really happened - not in a good way.  It also doesn't have some of the drama/surprise elements that it would probably have if it were being written as fiction. This is a true story which makes it so scary. Nicolas Cage is a cop who is sure he knows who the serial killer is was killing all the young girls in town. The killer is an upstanding citizens who has a family and owns the bakery in town. He actually kidnaps the girls then flies them in his private plane to a remote area, lets them go so they think they are free and start running through the forest like a deer and he proceeds to hunt them with his rifle.

This is just a note in passing this serial killer died in prison of a heart attack just last year.
Good movie I recommend.

(Nicholas Cage as Jack Halcombe, John Cusack as Robert Hansen and Vanessa Hudgens as Cindy Paulson).

1983 State of Alaska, North America. State trooper Jack Halcombe tries to get a warrant for the arrest of Robert Hansen after listening to the terrifying escape of Cindy Paulson from a man who frequented a night club picking up girls then flying them to a hideaway in the mountains where he would let the women go, terrified she would run into the woods to escape - Robert Hansen would then shoot the victim with a deer hunting rifle. When Jack Halcombe interviewed Robert Hansen, Hansen said that the girls kept asking for more money then Hansen put it back to Jack Halcombe saying "you know how it is". Jack Halcombe found Robert Hansen's Ute with the rifles in the boot and incidentally the matching bullets of the .223 caliber rifle used to shoot the escaping women. The judge would not hear the case because the rifle did not mean Robert Hansen had fired the rifle. Jack Halcombe presented a bangle from Susan and said "did you take the bangle off during or after interfering with Susan before killing her", Hansen still did not break. 17 year old Cindy Paulson stood at the opened door with an officer. Robert Hansen shouted "I should have killed you when I had the chance", witnessed by four officers. Robert Hansen had marked on a hunting map 24 shooting locations. Of the 17 reported missing, 11 were found shot in the back. Robert Hansen was sentenced in the state of Alaska to 461 years and life. A DVD in tribute to the memory of the many women who had tried and failed to escape.

Scott Walker writer and director. Best known for The Frozen Ground based on the case history of Robert Hansen.
We watched it because the plot looked intriguing, but then we discovered both the story and incredible acting of these two men, was worth every second of the film.

A true story taking place in Alaska portraying the dark side of life.  The tenacity of once state trooper's investigation brings a heinous wrong to justice.  The "afterlife" of the victims and characters brings one nearly to tears with a combination of sadness and happiness.
Not great, not terrible. The acting was good and the story was good. But, as an Alaskan there are some unbelievable "baloney" scenes, and too many shots of Anchorage from the air.

I saw the story on this serial killer on FBI Files, so I was excited that there was a movie about him. I cringed when I saw the three main actors, none of whom I think are very good. HOWEVER, I had to make one exception with this film. John Cusack was amazing - he had so much presence - I was really struck by how believable he was. I was really impressed with that. The scores were beautiful as was the cinematography. I didn't think that Nicolas or Vanessa pulled off their roles very well and a needless amount of time was spent at the strip clubs. I'm glad I watched it, once. Cusack made it worth while.

This is a dark, gritty movie based on the story of a young girl that got away from a serial killer in early 80s Alaska and the cop that got him. It is more a psychological thriller, with blood and gore kept to a minimum. The pace of the movie was good, allowing time for development of characters and suspense, but never so slow it got tiresome. I'm already a fan of Cusack, and his performance does not disappoint. I think Cage can be hit-and-miss, but he was very good in this role. I don't know much about Vanessa Hudgens' acting, but she did an amazing job playing a very troubled teenage prostitute/stripper here. The story is captivating (and horrifying)--especially since it was based on real events. This is definitely one of the better "true crime" movies I have seen.

The film is frightfully realistic.

Wow! This was a fantastic movie! The acting was superb! The plot was nail biting! I literally caught myself nervously fidgeting on several occasions.

I never figured out why people who comment, explain what the movie is about, as that is already covered by the trailer and the descriptions by the movie thumbnail. So I won't go over it again.

I thoroughly enjoyed this movie because it had so many twists, so much mystery, and I found myself really caring for the victim. Movies like this one prove what top rate acting can accomplish. It is no wonder that it got over 4000 reviews and most above average.

I even got massive chills at the end because it hadn't registered in my brain that this movie is based on actual events. When they showed pictures of the actual victims, it only amplified the anger that I felt towards the aggressor, and I won't spoil the outcome for you.

If you are unsure about what movie to rent and you are up for a detective, mystery, nail biting story line, this one is definitely a safe bet. I'd been wanting to watch it for the longest time, but it was much more expensive to rent it, a few months back, now it is under $3.00. A no brainer if you ask me!

A good freebie, but I would have been disappointed if I had paid full retail to see the flick.  It seems as though the writer was more interested in cataloging the horrendous demise of the many women killed by the murderer than in the true entertainment of the show; the killer's mind.  I also found it interesting that despite profession the female star is playing, we never see her in less than a bra and panties.  I also need to slam the director.  I've watch a number of Cage flicks, and know he is capable of portraying characters that totally suck me into the movie for a quarter hour at a time.  Not here though.  In fact, none of the acting showed very much intensity.  The story just plods along, with momentary spikes in action.  There was so much more that could have been done to portray the terror of the victims, the psyche of the murderer, the psyche of the cop, the involvement of the community.  I would have included news play, or something that would have heighten the viewer's involvement in the story.  In my opinion, there might have been more drama in the courtroom of the real killer, as the terrible, and frightening murders were described, than the events that were portrayed on the screen.  Obviously, the director was more interested in respecting the memories of the victims, than presenting a cinematic story that would grab the viewer from the now, and place them in the danger, or in the emotion of the pursuit of the criminal.

Well unfortunately this movie was really not paced well and all to often I found myself wondering if I hadn't just been better off watching an SVU rerun for free. Neither character ever felt to me like they got in the role and at every suspenseful turn there was no suspense. I don't want to give away any spoilers but suffice to say how you think it will end in the beginning is how it ends in the end. And I recognize it's based on a real story but even so a two hour dateline would be a better option than this.

Nicholas badges drivers a believable performance as a lead detective not willing to give up until a serial killer is found. A pretty good film about perhaps the worst serial killer in American history,
and what it took to bring him to justice. Some people knowledgeable about the
case and disappearances, believe he could have killed 50 to 70 young women.
Told through the eyes of law enforcement, this story details the one girl that
escaped his grasp when Bob Hansen was loading gear (and her) into his plane
to fly north to kill her in the Alaskan wilderness. She was the one girl who brought
him down, and ended his decade long heinous murder career. I have never much
liked John Cusack, or cared for his acting or roles that he played/casting, but this
is perhaps his best role/movie (or one of them), and more suits his particular talents/looks.

Vanessa Hudgens vacillates between cooperating with the cops and running back to her old life and the motivation isn't always clear. The scenes inside the strip clubs seem a trifle overdone, but maybe that's just me. No regrets for watching it, don't deem it worth watching again, will recommend it to others.

THE ONLY REASON THIS MOVIE IS RATED SO HIGH IS BECAUSE ITS BASED OFF A TRUE STORY. If it wasn't, no one would care and it would be considered a typical Nicholas Cage movie. The acting was fine but the script was terrible.

(Spoilers below)

A girl gets kidnapped but is intelligent enough to escape. Police investigate and know who the guy is. They have her testimony, other victims testimonies, and the murder weapons - yet the district attorney has to have a confession...? Then a police officer randomly presents a map with all the grave-sites...and they still MUST have him confess.

Then the "intelligent" girl who recently ran into the murderer...decides to flee from police protection. She gets snatched up by a bad guy, taken to a site to be killed...and luckily gets away. With a huge headstart, the bad guy somehow follows her in his car and instead of going to say a populated place (a diner, walmart, busy gas station, club, etc) she goes to the one place he can easily get to her. Just terrible.

This was an excellent dramatization of the Robert Hansen serial killer case from Alaska. Hansen was portrayed very convincingly by John Cusack, and Nic Cage was great as Sgt Jack Halcombe of the Alaska State Trooper's office. The acting was very realistic to me; the sets and cinematography were great. There was nothing that pulled me out of the story to say Wait! that doesn't fit! which is always a frustrating feeling when you are watching a movie.
This was kind of an interesting take on the thriller genre, because you pretty much know from the opening scenes who the bad guy is. All along, you are rooting for the investigators and hoping they can catch a break so this guy is caught. Every time there's a setback the tension ratchets up because it is no longer a question of whodunit but will they get him? One thing that really caught my attention was the very unconcerned attitudes of the DA/cops when Cindy reports the rape/assault she experienced at Hanson's hands. There was definitely an attitude that she was just a pros and therefore it wasn't worth their time to even pick up the rape kit from the hospital. I think that's probably a large part of why Hansen got away with his crimes for so long - he chose invisible women to attack, rape, and murder. Had Cindy Paulson not escaped, he might have continued his string of murders until he was just physically no longer able to kill. Chilling thought.
The cars, clothing, etc. were so perfect. Ah the 1970s/80s, how I don't miss your style!
All in all I think this was a good movie. There were definitely moments of tension that moved the story forward, and even the slow moments didn't really make the movie drag on. In fact, the slow parts increased the realism of the fact that sometimes, investigations stall because there is just no other place to go until some situation changes.
The movie is rated "R" so you should know there's some "bad" stuff, besides the obvious story line. There are boobs everywhere in the strip club/dance club scenes. Also, thong panties just make your butt look weird. Just sayin.' The F-bomb was used so many times I couldn't even count it. There are gruesome scenes of torture and murder that are not bloody explicit but are jarring nonetheless. There is an attempted abduction/murder that is very intense. So obviously this is for adults only. It is a sobering story, too, because of the nature of the beast that is the serial killer. In one way it is satisfying to see them brought to justice, but it is in another way sad to see that some people are just wired wrong.
I hope you enjoy the movie if you decide to watch it.

Fairly bland and unfocused film about an actual serial killer in Alaska from the early '80s. Lots of cliches and predictable characters. Unfortunate in that it has a very capable cast. John Cusack had the makings of a creepy serial killer who lives among us - seemingly good citizen masking his dark side to family and co-workers. He doesn't get the opportunity to take it anywhere as scenes with family, friends and even victims are brief. Not enough to develop the horror lurking beneath his calm exterior. Similarly, half-hearted attempt at rendering the family conflicts that Nicholas Cage wrestles with while pursuing the case. Much is unexplained about the killer's history and current community status or how he can realistically pursue his criminal activities.

With all that said, if you like these two actors, there's enough there to sustain a lazy Sunday afternoon. If these actors don't entice you, don't waste your time.

This is based on true events.  Nicolas Cage and John Cusack do a wonderful job at portraying their true to life characters.  I was drawn in by Nicolas Cages compulsion to find the killer portrayed by John Cusack.  John was a scary s.o.b. who makes you think that anyone you meet in your life could be this guy. The story is literally dark and depressing and each character continuously adds to an inescapable feeling of doom. There is no real happy ending unless you want to call surviving after being tortured and almost murdered a good thing.  These kind of memories never go away.  I cant imagine how a person gets over this life altering experience.  In any event, if you like based on a real story serial killer movies, this one should be added to your collection.

Superb retelling of real-life crime drama in idyllic Alaska that I had never heard of until now.  The script is good, the acting terrific, and the crimes too horrible to imagine.  You pretty much know who the bad guy is early on, but the suspense of the movie lies in watching the culprit literally get away with murder until law enforcement can gather enough evidence to remove this monster from society.  The film gives a worthy tribute to all known and suspected victims at the end, affording many the dignity that they may not have received in life.
Keeps your attention to the very end.  These two stars work really well together.

Not for the faint of heart, and if you have teenage daughters I would pass. Otherwise an extraordinary acting performance by John Cusack as a serial killer makes it totally worth while.  What this film does very well is show the banality of evil as Nicholas Cage's cop doggedly tracks Cusack's sicko character. Cage plays it pretty deadpan, he is the tent-pole of the story and is solid all the way.

Alaska itself becomes a character in the story, nothing like that stupid Northern Exposure show, the tourism board is probably horrified at the portrayal of Alaska as land of whores and strip clubs surrounded by cavemen and wilderness and lazy turf-warring cops, where teenage girls bodies are only found when a bear digs them up. Not for the squeamish, but they don't over-linger on the yuck either, just enough to make the point.

The movie was just okay. There were a lot of familiar faces in the cast, all of whom did a superb job of acting. Since it was based on a true story, there's not much I can say for the storyline. It was pretty straightforward with not a whole lot of surprises. The cops knew who the killer/rapist was so their MO was to get proof to take him in. What made the movie almost unbearable to watch, however, was the cinematography and bad editing. I know they were going for an ominous feel, but everything was way too dark. I adjusted my TV every way I could and still could barely see anything. It didn't help that all the girls had pitch black hair and the guys wore black and all the citizens wore black. Against a dark, dim background (in Alaska winter, when it's hardly daylight anyway), it was very difficult to distinguish one character from another.  The sound was awful too.  The music was too loud and voices barely audible. Thank goodness for closed captioning.

Great movie direction and exposition of real life events of Robert Hansen Alaska's infamous serial killer. This movie was well done and did not allow a moment of inattention. All actors were superb in their roles. One surviver, Cindy Paulson was instrumental in the conviction of Robert Hansen. The credits displayed the victims pictures, the year of their abduction, and if their bodies were located. A very strong conclusion for this must see movie.

This film was done with a cast of wonderful actors. I did not like John Cusack, playing the part of a psychopathic killer---NOT AT ALL. He is so miscast in this film, even though he does a good job; It is hard to wrap your head around beloved John acting in such a frightening way.

The story, because it is a true account of a serial killer, is very disturbing. This is a dark film, which tells the account of very horrible murders that took place in Alaska over a long period of time.  There are no scenes of grieving parents, or any exploitation of families. The film deals with the police work involved in apprehending the killer. The Justice that is delivered, cannot erase the reality of all who died because of this madman.

My four star choice is because I did not care for John Cusack in his role as murderer.

I rented this one not really knowing what it was about - and I think I'll probably spend the rest of the night a little nauseated. It's hard to imagine that evil like this can exist in the world. I was definitely shocked by this movie. That said, I did think it was really well done.

I picked this up because I LOVE John Cusack and because I lived in Alaska for two years. Guess I should have read the back cover a little more carefully, lol! The Frozen Ground is basically a suspense thriller about the horrific actions of a prolific serial killer and an Alaska Trooper's determination to stop him. There's a lot of nudity, quite a few f-bombs, and many shockingly violent scenes involving women being tortured and murdered. Thankfully none of the rape scenes were actually shown.

Usually I can't stomach movies like this, but this film did a really nice job of portraying the violence without glorifying it. I may have picked it up by accident, but I was drawn in by the suspense. It was heart-wrenching to learn what these women went through, but I thought the producers and actors told the story in an extremely respectful way. Obviously a movie about a serial killer is going to have disturbing scenes, but it was done in such a way that I felt like I was being shown what happened so that I would UNDERSTAND, not so that I would be entertained - if that makes sense.

My only complaint is that Cusack was cast as the serial killer. Don't get me wrong - he was very convincing. And I can understand why he was cast - this monster was *that* guy - the one who leads the double life. You hear stories about serial killers who are upstanding members of their community - little league coaches and such - and when they're caught no-one can believe it because they seemed so nice and normal. Who better to portray that then someone like Cusack? It was just hard for ME, personally, to watch a favorite, lovable actor portray someone so horrific.

Definitely worth watching, but not buying. It's well done, well acted, and very suspenseful - but I couldn't endure watching this kind of violence a second time. I think I've checked the locks on my doors three times already tonight, and I'm pretty sure I'm going to have nightmares.

**MINOR SPOILER** - the most shocking part of this entire movie (for me) was during the end credits. I just sat there, watching those faces flash by...completely stunned. Nothing could have made a bigger impact than that. I can't even wrap my brain around such pure evil existing in this world. May those women rest in peace.

This is a typical movie of its time. Bad and illogical script, endless location jumps, incredible coincidences. People find people all over Alaska without any hint (or at least no hint ever disclosed to the viewer). Cage's character interviews the only living witness a couple of times (seems to find her wherever she is) without ever asking about what the guy looks like. Then Cage's character interviews Cusacks's character, they talk like forever about what not, instead of letting the witness id him. Really....?

On the tech side: Shaky bwp-like picture, unwatchable on anything larger than a mobile phone. A cut every 2 seconds. Gives you a headache and is a waste of time. Cusack and Cage both stopped making good movies around 2000, period.

The Frozen Ground is a thriller based on the real-life hunt for serial killer Robert Hansen at Alaska during the 1980's. It was reported that the said serial killer has stalked and murdered between seventeen to twenty- one young women. Apparently,he would kidnap them and take them out to the wilderness where he shot and buried them. It stars Nicolas Cage as Sgt. Jack Halcombe,which was based on the character of Alaskan detective that captured the killer,Glenn Flothe; and John Cusack as Hansen himself.

This is a well-paced and engaging film feature. Despite the fact that the movie is something that we have already seen before in other thrillers and that it is far from being refreshing and original,we get to see great performances from both Cage and Cusack. It is also worth mentioning that it is a solid film and it will definitely provide a lot of thrills and entertainment to the viewer especially during Halcombe's investigation of the murders. But inspite of it,it falls short as there were a lot of plot holes like a character analysis of Hansen on his motive of committing those crimes as well as the other victims apart from Paulson. Too bad that it could have been better since this is obviously made as a lasting tribute to the victims of Hansen.

I don't typically give a movie 5 stars unless it is one that I would want to watch over and over.  This one to me was almost good enough to get 5 stars except I would not want to watch it over and over.  I felt like the acting in the movie was very good for all 3 of the main characters.  I also was drawn into each of them and was trying to imagine what their lives would be like.  The back and forth between the state trooper (Nicholas Cage) and the victim that got away and was the key to his case (Vanessa Hudgens) seemed very realistic.  The fact that it was based on a true story was even more interesting.

I would have liked a bit more insight into the family life of the Serial Killer (John Cusack).  They did show many examples of how he seemed to be a respected member of the community and they showed one scene that might have indicated that it was not all roses, but it would have been interesting to see more.  People like that generally have a dark side that you can see more easily from those really close to them.  I felt John Cusack did a fantastic job with the character.

A movie like this makes me want to get into law enforcement to help find and prosecute evil people such as the killer in this movie.  It makes me wonder how many others are out there doing these despicable things for many years without anyone knowing.  I truly feel sorry for all of his victims and their families.  I hope his capture and prosecution was able to bring them some closure and they are able to move on.  These killers are just the scum of the earth with no regard for anyone but themselves.  It is hard to imagine how someone could be so callous and uncaring.  To put someone through hell like that only to kill them for sport when he tired of them is unfathomable to me.  Just think of all of the people's lives that were impacted negatively by just this one person.  I said some prayers for all the families of his victims after watching this movie since I imagine coping with this happening to your daughter, sister, niece, friend, etc would be difficult.

I highly recommend watching this movie.

We were pleasantly surprised by this movie and the dramatic story that unfolded as we watched the drama. Acting was good and the cast was very well known. It definitley was a sleeper movie and unexpected but so sad to know it was a true story!

Very disturbing story about an even more disturbing man. There is a scene in which a young lady is shot while running in the woods. The film-makers did an amazingly accurate job of capturing the look on a human's face as their life ebbs away. I have worked in the ICU setting for nearly 30 years and have witnessed that same look as patients lose their fight for life. For those that live in their little white houses with the little white picket fence that keep reality at bay, this movie is not for you.  The gritty side of reality has not changed (1960's, 1970's, 1980's, 1990's, 2000's, 2010's) because humans have not changed.  These types of people still exist (Green River Killer-Gary Ridgeway, Hillside Strangler, Ted Bundy, BTK, Robert Yates, to name just a few).  If you were to google serial killers you will get some idea of what I am talking about.  The movie is reasonably accurate in portraying the underbelly of society in Alaska (Anchorage) at the time.  That's the thing about serial killers, they don't stand out.  Just think about the ones that have not yet been found out because they have not yet made a mistake that brings to light their activities.  A good, gritty movie.

Too voyeuristic for me. I prefer more character development. It would have been interesting to learn more about  Robert Hansen
(Cusack's character), not just the how but the why. How many people remained silent for him to get away with it for so long? This movie didn't delve into any of this instead just kept taking the viewer back into a strip club.  Expecting you to take everything at face value. Mediocre at best.

Being from Alaska, I was at first hesitant to watch yet another movie about Alaska.  I knew it was filmed in Alaska, and that was the main reason I wanted to watch it at first - to see my home State on the big screen coming out of Hollywood.  And I wasn't disappointed.  Lots and lots of beautiful scenery of this beautiful state, as well as the local Anchorage area.  And while the scenery was my first draw to the movie, I was pleasantly surprised as I watched Nicholas Cage and John Cusack in a pretty good story about Alaska's own serial killer.  I recommend the movie.  A decent watch.

While the movie was done well as a thriller and the "villain" was perfectly portrayed, the excessive "adult language" makes it impossible for me to recommend to anyone I care about. It's puzzling to me that Hollywood insists that this kind of dialog is the best way to reach adult audiences. It's also a good "work-around" for those in the industry who can't accurately portray anger in their character. "Throwing F-bombs at high volume means he's mad," seems to be all the direction some people need. Even if, occasionally, the profanity was justified, the pervasive use of it degrades rather than enhances the quality of the film.

Please don't think this is language I've never heard outside of a film. I have worked with the military since 1971. I have no "virgin ears." I'd just rather not have it as part of my entertainment.

With two 4 stars actors in Nicolas Cage and John Cusack I expected so much more. But I guess because this is based on a true story the screenplay didn't have much wiggle room. This picture is slow and tedious because we know all that we need to know from the very beginning but we are forced to wait almost 2 hours for it to happen. If you enjoy films where you get to follow the lives of three individuals until a conclusion is reached. Then this is a film for you. Nicolas gives an impassioned performance and Cusack makes you believe that he believes everything that he says. I guess if you enjoy watching the investigative parts of police work, observing the addicts and mentally ill at work, then you may want to see this film. But I do not think that you will watch it more than once.

This film just misses being great.. It is apparently based on facts and all the acting was quite good. Never has Alaska itself seemed more sinister. The country itself seemed like an accomplice to the crimes of this psychopath played convincingly by John Cusak. I could have used a little more back story of the killer himself and his normal, non-descript life that prevented police from pinning anything on him for a long time. The story in this movie moves along very quickly and it seems almost too easy for Nicolas Cage's character to put it all together. Other than that, it is worth your time and well done.

I love movies based on real characters and happenings, and thiis serial killer is an intriguing, especially sadistic one. I watched the movie the day the real killer died in prison at age 75. It was an uninspired treatment of the real-life situation. Nicholas Cage was Nicholas Cage, as always, and fun, as his acting style is, but he didn't bring anything to his part. However, John Cusack was outstanding as the killer. He looked like pictures of the actual killer, and lost himself in the role and gave a very real portrayal of the real killer...I wasn't reminded that he was John Cusack during the movie. His performance and the gory real-life details of the plot, and the stark forbidding shots of Alaska make the movie worth watching.

I moved to Anchorage, AK in the Fall of 1981 and remember following this case closely pre and post arrest.
This movie which was filmed in Anchorage does a credible job telling this horrific story.
The main actors give solid performances especially Vanessa Hudgens as the lone survivor and only eyewitness.

I watched this movie last night and I loved how it was done. My husband and I were stationed there at the time this was going on. People were talking about this everywhere. I was just barely 18 years old at the time and I remember the military wives who were in their mid twenties asking why call girls and dancers were the victims. The first thought in my mind was "no one cares about them and no one is going to miss them." Being young, I spoke those words out loud in a quiet tone. Nicolas Cage and John Cusack did an amazing job in their portrayal of their roles. I have to say that John Cusack did an amazing job at playing a serial killer. I was so impressed by his skills as an actor and I am an even bigger fan of his skill because of this movie. When Nicolas Cage first came out I was not impressed by him but as the years went by I have become a fan of this amazing actor. The man is a talented actor and I love that I don't need closed captions to understand the words coming out of his mouth. It doesn't matter what accent he uses but I can clearly hear the words he speaks. The scenes in the movie that showcase Alaska is real. It may have been a long time since I have been in Anchorage but one never does forget the beauty of the state of Alaska. I do believe that if my memory serves me correctly that that may have been the actual Police Station when we were there 30 something years ago. Be prepared to be blown away and impressed with the quality of the script, acting skills, how the film was shot and by the amazing skill of John's portrayal of how a serial killer should be done.

I will try not to be too critical or prejudicial as I write this. I definitely remember when the actual case "broke open" as I was an Investigator on the Anchorage Police Department at the time (now retired APD), though not involved in this case. I had worked on Alaska State Troopers before joining APD so I personally knew (and still do)  several of the officers depicted in the movie from both the Anchorage Police and Troopers. Real life investigations are never as exciting as they are on the screen, so I will say that I certainly enjoyed the movie and would recommend it to crime buffs. For me, it was especially fun to see some of the Anchorage sights on screen; the downstairs bar scene had to be representing the old well known sleazy  Elbow Room which often required Police attention in those days. Both Cage and Cuzak kept the dark mood of the film moving and entertaining, though occasionally, the soundtrack got in the way of the dialogue of the characters. AND, though I know many who did, I was not one of the officers who could admit being a customer of Hansen's bakery!  Thankfully!

coincidental but were few and far between.

I applaud the real Halcombe for pursuing this complex case and
delivering a modicum of justice. This aspect of society is typically
relegated to smirk filled TV shorts that do not capture the intense
fear and terror many feel in a big city let alone a remote part of the
world.

What is the message here? You can't choose your parents and protectors,
stay away from the pole and nightlife in general, the police are easily
prejudiced against females, die with dignity, and most of all carry
pepper spray!

A prostitute escapes from a customer she says raped and tried to kill her. The detectives called in to investigate brush aside both her accusation and her story because of who she is. They don't even collect the rape kit for evidence. The patrolman who brought her in believes her, however, and mails copies of all the available reports to the Alaska State Troopers, and Jack Halcombe, who is two weeks away from transferring out, is assigned the case. In short order, Halcombe connects this one to several others occurring in the same area over years and since they now have a survivor, he's certain they can bring the man suspected in those cases to justice. It's a long and frustrating task, however, blocked by the girl's reluctance to testify due to the initial reception of her story, the killer's self-confidence he can't be touched, and the prosecutor's demand for enough evidence the case won't be thrown out of court.

This is a rather leisurely-paced film with very little in the way of blood and gore or any of the usual serial killer movies.  More attention is paid to Halcombe, the witness Cindy, and the investigation than in the killer himself or his actual motives.  Nicolas Cage is his usual driven self, Victoria Hudgens projects a tough girl/vulnerable waif-like quality as Cindy, and John Cusak still manages to look nerdy enough, even at his age, to appear harmless while being internally a vicious cold-blooded murderer.

The Alaskan landscape in winter provides a beautiful, cold, and frightening backdrop for this drama, showing how vast an area the troopers had to cover, and how easy it would be to lose a body, evidence, or even one's-self in the trees, mountains, and snow in an area better accessible by plane rather than car or on foot.  The story may not be as tense or gritty as some but it plainly points out, unfortunately, that even our remote 49th state isn't immune to the ills the rest of the nation suffers, and killers can exist even in such a beautiful place.

The posting of photographs of the real victims behind the end credits, and noting whether or not their bodies were ever recovered and/or identified (and it's noted several are marked as "not known if identified") is a chilling addendum to the story, as well as the fact that a good many of the victims were never found and it's believed there were many, many more than the killer admitted to.

This outstanding movie tells the frightening, true story of convicted serial killer Robert Hansen, who raped and murdered several young women in Alaska between 1971 and 1983.  Nicholas Cage is intense as Alaska State Trooper homicide detective Jack Halcombe - based on real-life detective Glenn Flothe - determined to capture psycho killer Hansen, who is brilliantly portrayed by John Cusack: very low-key and good-natured on the surface, but displaying a cold, frightening brutality towards the women he sexually assaulted and murdered.  Hansen led a double life, a real Jekyll and Hyde: on the surface, he was the successful owner of a bakery, very quiet, very religious, a married man with two children.  His inner, dark world seethed with perverted, evil, and murderous misogyny, bubbling and oozing to the surface as he preyed on young women in the seamy, tough areas of Anchorage; many - although not all - of his victims were prostitutes and strippers. An avid hunter, he tracked and killed these young women just as he did the animals whose heads were nailed to the walls of his home. The lovely and very talented Vanessa Hudgens was perfect, just spot-on, as Hansen's real-life victim, Cindy Paulson - a tough-talking yet extremely vulnerable young street waif turned hooker, who was the only one who lived to tell.  It was her testimony in court which helped to convict Robert Hansen, who was sentenced to 461 years plus life in prison without parole; he will never be freed.  This powerful, intense, harrowing, and rather violent movie is not for the squeamish; however, it is exceptionally well-made and definitely worth watching.  *ETA on 08/24/2014: Hansen just died 10 days ago, on 08/14/2014, due to "undisclosed, lingering health conditions".  One less serial killer to torment innocent people.

The Frozen Ground is based on the true story of serial killer Robert Hansen, who terrorized Alaska during  80s, during which time there were many reports of missing women as well as mysterious deaths in  Alaskan wilderness. In the film, a state trooper (Nicholas Cage) comes to believe that the string of deaths and missing person reports all come from one source, a respectable member of the community. Cindy Paulson, a teenager who had managed to escape Hansen, becomes a key witness in this case.

What I liked about The Frozen Ground is that, while the film does have elements of a crime thriller we've seen before, it has solid acting from several of the leads that make it go beyond an average thriller. Cage does an exceptional job of handling this role with a scaled-down, subtle realness. He tries to bring this cold-case back to life, and pin down enough evidence on the suspect to get a case. As real life Jack Halcombe, he tries to help Cindy get over the emotional trauma of her horrifying encounter all the while trying to track a madman. John Cusack plays the creepy role of Hansen to perfection. Vanessa Hudgens gives a stellar performance as Cindy.

I saw an interview with Nicolas Cage where he was talking about this film and preparing for the role. In it, he was discussing how he met with the real-life detective who was responsible for bringing Hansen to justice, and considered him a hero for his efforts. He got much of the background for this story and a feel for the person he was portraying. This is quite evident in the film. A really good performance.

This film, as expected, does have some disturbing content based on its subject. We are taken through the world of strip clubs and prostitution and the seedy parts of the community. There are also moments of violence that are disturbing.  I think these moments, though, give a stark realness to the setting and events that took place.

A powerful thriller. One to definitely check out.

Nick Cage is Nick Cage as the relentless cop on the hunt for the perpetrator.
John Cusack delivers a good creepy performance as the accused.
Vanessa Hudgens is a runaway who has taken to prostitution and stripping, leading to her abduction.
Ultimately the film made me disturbed that this type of thing actually happens in the world, but I guess that means that the movie was successful in telling the story.

Worth watching.  It is a little slow in some areas, but overall a good movie.

Nicolas Cage looks a bit younger than he has in the last few movies I've watched of his, PLUS the movie really does have a 1980's vintage look (because that is the era these events transpired) ...So for a little while I though I had somehow rented an older movie.

It is a good movie, very well made with solid acting performances throughout. I took away 1 star because the movie gets a little bit bogged down using strip clubs and substance abuse as a way to add intensity and drama, whereas I have seen enough scenes like those in movies that it isn't particularly pulse elevating to watch. (Spring Breakers & The Bling Ring also heavily rely on "the bad element" of nightclubs & drug use to show the viewers "how bad these people are..." and it's almost laughable in this day and age) So this movie lost a star for not finding a more original way to add intensity to the story.
Good movie, good acting and good subject! This one will heat you up exponentially as the story progresses to it's conclusion.
As always, a really good movie by Nicolas Cage. It will keep you in suspense as he a temps to solve the case. Enjoyed every minute of it.
Don't know how we ever missed this in the past, great movie. Would recommend it to everyone who likes an action movie..
true story suspense with beautiful scenery in Alaska

Such a disappointment and one of the worst films I've seen in recent history.  Don't let the big named stars in the movie fool you.  This is not worth your time to watch.  No wonder I'd never heard of this movie even though its from 2013.  Sadly, the story is interesting and the plot is enticing but unfortunately I would not recommend this movie

THAT WAS A MOVIE YOU FELT SORRY FOR THE WOMEN HE KILLED BUT GOOD THE ONE GOT AWAY.IT WAS GOOD SHE HELPED PUT HIM AWAY.

Had a good storyline and painfully truthful. The addition of 50cent was just poor choice and added absolutely nothing! Way too many scenes of the strip bars that I missed some portions due to fast forwarding.
this was a good movie based on a true story. The cast had good star power and was well acted. It was a good movie and I enjoyed it.

This could have used significant editing. The plot was often confusing, with many jumps that made no sense. First rate acting by John Cusak and Dean Norris. Scenes of Alaska are stunning, but it seems much of the city views were done elsewhere. Overall, 2-1/2 stars.

This is the true story a serial killer  attacking at will. Local police and district attorney would consider him and would dismiss any victim reports. It took the State Police investigators risking jobs and retirement to even off-time investigate this predator.  Well worth watching.
Good acting, a good story line and great location all make this a really good movie. I would recommend it!

Based on an actual series of incidents in Anchorage back in the 80s, this drama is not for the light of heart.  The writers allow for the characters to develop, something that Hollywood movies often ignore.  Nicholas Cage and John Cusak (Especially John Cusak) turn in surprising realistic performances.  But note: Cusack's character is not the usual Cusack kind of character.  Don't bring up this film on your Prime viewer if you're expecting a comedy romp or a light hearted approach to crime.  Cage and Cusack are playing serious dramatic roles, they are doing it in all seriousness and there is nothing short of reality in the way this is done.  If you're a fan of crime documentaries or serious crime dramas you will be pleasantly surprised.  If you're looking for just another Cage or Cusack vehicle you should go to "2012" or "Face Off" because this is one heck of a serious film.
THIS MOVIE EVERYONE SHOULD WATCH. HAS A GOOD STORY TO IT. GOOD POLICE WORK SOLVE THE VICTIM MULESTOR , IS AWESOME MOVIE. I RECOMENDED FOR ALL TO WATCH.
My husband, daughter and I all enjoyed this movie.  Pretty suspenseful throughout. We are Nicolas Cage fans and this was a typical Nicolas Cage movie.

The key to this movie is that it is based on actual events.  There is the drama of the personal life of the lead detective (cage), and that of the girl that escapes, but the best part is the last 30 minutes, that lead up to the end result.  Worth a watch.
Captivating story....disturbing at times if you allow yourself  to get really into it and come to the realization that this monster really still lives in Alaska's prisons system!

Is unbelievable that this was a real story!! Recommended!! This a dark movie but at the end everything change... A++

I wonder if it even made it to the theaters and if it did, it must not have been there very long.
I have to say, this was the most boring, boring, boring movie I have ever watched. It was hard to follow the story line at all. Boring
Pretty good overall.  A little more conservative role for Nickolas Cage. I liked the ending. Overall I liked it for a free movie.

Unfortunately, this movie's plot was based on truth.  It is disturbing,violent, and gritty, but I really liked that it didn't show the violence.  It showed enough for you to get the idea.  I would not watch this with anyone under 16.

This supposed thriller is supposedly based on the 1980s hunt for Alaskan serial killer Robert Hansen who had murdered 17-21 young women after kidnapping them and taking them out into the Alaskan wilderness.

The problem with the film is that the case should have been solved in 5 minutes - simply by having the one survivor, Cindy, ID Hansen. Neither the Anchorage PD nor the Alaska State Police did so - until the very end.

There was also an obvious overtone of prosecutors and detectives being extremely overly deferential to suspect Hansen, but never any explanation of why - especially given that he had been convicted of several somewhat similar crimes.
Nick Cage is a believable character in this police drama. John Cusack plays a demented killer and does it well!

Strong casting, especially with John Cusack in the chilling role of Robert Hansen.  Plausible psychological drama between cop and killer, and between cop and witness.  Also believably uncooperative behavior from Vanessa Hudgens in her supporting role. Otherwise nothing ground-breaking (so to speak) in plot or execution. Maybe a bit heavy-handed in depicting the "system" as an obstacle to justice.  So, some familiar cliches.  Overall, the film went a bit beyond my expectations for a police procedural.
We enjoyed this movie.  Not sure why we missed it in the theaters.  Good plot and the acting was good.

Good thriller, great actors!
Very scary that it's based on a true story.
I love to watch suspenseful drama.
Fast paced.

I am partial to movies based on true life adventures.  This one is an adventure for sure, although a very tragic and sad one.  I feel the movie was very well orchestrated.  I read some of the other reviews and really didn't quite understand the negative comments.  But I guess to each his own.  Excellent movie.
Pretty good. Good cast, could have used some more action, but understand it is based on a true story. End

Based on a true story of an Alaskan State Trooper. If all police would work as hard as he did to solve a case, there would be a lot less cold cases.

I live in Alaska and I found too many things about the film totally wrong.  Little things like the number of people on the street in Anchorage at night (I've never seen it that busy) to the time the "bad" guy takes off in his airplane from Merril Field in the middle of a snow storm without clearance from ground control or the tower.  Just so many things wrong.  I could go on and on....... just sayin'

What a powerful story and cast! All of the main actors are compelling and totally believable. When John Cusack's facial muscles started to twitch I thought I'd start twitching myself. The suspense builds so gradually that you suddenly realize your hands are in fists. Whether you know the story or not, you are so afraid for Cindy. I just wanted to hold her still until she saw reason, but her behavior was absolutely true to how she would feel - convinced that no one would really do anything to save her. BUT someone did!

Aging is tough on the body and the psyche.  In the simultaneous struggle to maintain one's career, it is tempting to compromise.  In this movie, Cage has done exactly that.  If I wanted a monitor full of boobs and bottoms, I would go to a porn site.  If I want a movie where the good guy has to recognize quality in someone of a different culture, I look for Nicolas Cage.  But not so in this movie.  This is porn and nothing more.  It exploits the illicit and illegal prostitution of foolish young women into--you guessed it--illicit prostitution of foolish young women AND a foolish Nicolas Cage.
I like movies based on fact. I also like Nicolas Cage's acting style. Thought the movie was well done and it kept me interested and entertained.
Very suspenseful and always movin!.  I recomend this thriller to anyone who likes to wonder what is going to happen next!
it is an edge of your seat drama. Beautiful scenery in anchorage Alaska. A true story of a man whose own family didn't suspect.
Really good watch if you like thrillers.  Great story and could not stop watching.  Definetly going to watch this again
After you've watched it you think, "so what".  its a bland story, the characters aren't appealing and Anchorage doesn't feel like anchorage of 30+ year ago.

Boring!...furthermore not as good as most tv movies......................don't waste your time on this garbage!...
