Anchorage in summer is the place where tens of thousands of tourists arrive by air, road, or cruise ship to see mainland Alaska.  Half an hour from Anchorage in any direction puts the visitor in the middle of the some of the most beautiful wild country left in North America.  Anchorage itself is pretty enough in summer.  In winter, however, the visitors leave, and Anchorage folds back in on itself, to hunker down and wait out the long cold dark.  Once upon a time, it was a happy hunting ground for a serial killer...

"The Frozen Ground" is the dramatization of the investigation into serial killer Robert Hansen of Anchorage, still known as "butcher baker" among local law enforcement.  Nicholas Cage plays stalwart Alaska State Trooper Jack Halcombe, who leads the investigation, assisted by Vanessa Hudgens as the young prostitute Cindy, one of Hansen's would-be victims who managed to escape.  John Cusack is chilling as the seemingly unremarkable Hansen, a baker, husband and father with a vicious hobby.  The movie includes a prolonged dive into the gritty underbelly of Anchorage, with its bars, prostitution, drug use, and violence, where a clever killer could hang out for years without even being noticed.

The viewer knows early the identity of the killer; the drama of the movie is in the struggle to find the evidence to arrest Hansen before he can kill again.  At the end, Halcombe and his law enforcement partners will be pushed into a tough corner, racing the clock to get Hansen before he can get rid of the evidence and the principal witness.  The movie benefits from its location shooting in and around Anchorage, including the Knik River, the Chugach Mountains, and the Matanuska Glacier.  The dark and the cold help shape the atmospherics of a tense thriller, told almost in documentary style.  It is a solid movie with a disturbing after-taste, although it might mean less to outsiders than to Alaskans who can appreciate how it all played out.  Recommended.

I THINK ANYTHING THAT HAS NICHOLAS CAGE IN IT IS A MUST.  THIS KEEPS YOU ON THE END OF THE SEAT OF YOUR COUCH.
Nicolas Cage and John Cusack are very good in this true story. The Cusack character is especially troubling because he seems so normal in everyday life.

This is the first movie in a long, long time that Nicolas Cage has been in that was above mediocre, or worse.  The casting of John Cusack against type was a huge benefit to the storyline, and re-confirms my belief in his acting ability (that is under-utilized).  There were some stereotypical characters, but it was one of the best of the detective genre to come out in a while.  This was also enhanced by the setting - not the gritty-city environment, and by the fact that is was based on a true story.

"Frozen Ground" displays the Alaskan wilderness to perfection, in all its cold and terrible beauty.  Even within the city of Anchorage, the winter's darkness rules, snow covers the roads, and in one great scene, the heroine confronts a moose in a back alley (yep, that happens in Anchorage!)

And then we go inside out of the cold:  into the middle class home of the policeman, and of the killer.  The latter glories in a basement lined with animal trophies he has collected over the years:  he is, after all, a really ace hunter.  The other warm places are the bars and stripjoints, dimly lit, and crowded with men on a party, loaded with Pipeline money, and the girls plying their own trades of stripping and prostitution.  (Actually, I wonder if there was pole dancing back then?  I don't think so.)

The acting was first rate.  John Cusack was up to his usual high standard.  Nicholas Cage was a totally believable policeman.  And Vanessa Hudgens did a very fine job as Cindy the One who Got Away from the killer.  She looks like a baby at times, and then rolls to sullen, and then blank fear.  The cop's wife was a weak story and a weak role for any actress; in fact, almost embarrassingly foolish.  But this was the only part of the movie that disappoints.

This is not a slasher movie.  It takes the real story of the killings seriously, and carefully.  And it treats the victims with respect.

We didn't watch the movie.  It was clear fairly quickly that this was a porn project, as many films are these days.  How can we introduce porn and make it seem like it's a necessary part of the movie? The porn and the gratuitously graphic language have no point.  It's not a thriller, not psychologically interesting.  The fact that someone would do this with a supposedly real event makes me question who we are.  I can't understand any actor willing to do this, but what is the matter with women?  The word "No" and having some dignity isn't more important than the money, is it?  Just the worst.

I really enjoyed this movie but, to be honest, I probably am biased by the shoot location.  This was filmed right down the road from where I live on the Knik River (where Hansen put most of the bodies).  As such, I was probably more interested than most but really enjoyed the movie.
Nick shows his age a bit in this flick but still keeps your eyes glued to the screen.  Not one of his greats but still worthwhile.

For a movie I had never heard of with these two I thought this finished product must have been less than ideal for a straight to DVD romp.  However this movie was a nice lil surprise and I highly recommend it, especially if you like this genre.  Both actors were outstanding in the movie, John Cusack as criminal and Nicholas Cage as the cop. The story is about Cusack and his shady past but rehabiltated image as a well liked man in the local donut/bakery/coffee shop family man who is hiding a dark secret.  Cage is a Detective who is 2 weeks away from a transfer and gets assigned the typical homicide case that turns out to be more than a mouthful.  Cage's intensity helped a lot and you could feel it in his performance.  Cusack, who I had never seen in this sort of role was great as you could see and feel the pressure and tension mounting on both characters.  In the middle is a young female victim who is a witness who wasn't taken seriously by investigators bc of her social class and character, she's a teen prostitute runaway.

This is a movie based on real events which also always adds a bit of authenticity for me but there were those moments that just weren't fleshed out that great.  I'm a stickler for detail and this was missing attention to it at times and the story of Cusack could have been developed a bit more considering the historical perspective we have on his character.  We just sort of jump right in and take off running which isn't always bad but there was a fair amount of material to draw from and seemed like a missed opportunity.  Overall though it was really good, 50 cent cast as a pimp with long-braided hair was pretty funny. Not a good personal look for him and I'm also not a fan of him in movies at all, he has a descent amount of screen time and thought that could have been better served by an actor  instead of a hip-pop star.

Inspired by a real-life case of a serial killer Robert Hansen, The Frozen Ground stars Nicholas Cage as an Alaska state trooper Jack Halcombe determined to bring the murderer to justice. To do so, Jack needs a help from a teenage girl named Cindy Paulson (Vanessa Hudgens), the only survivor of the killing spree of Robert Hansen (John Cusack), who passes for an upstanding citizen.

Story-wise The Frozen Ground doesnt break any new ground. The truths about what Robert Hansen did to the victims are shocking, but the story itself seems very formulaic, with a concluding third act that is a bit too short. Interestingly, writer/director Scott Walker spends considerable time following the relationship between Jack and Cindy, while some viewers might want to see Jack hunting down the killer.

With strong performances from Nicolas Cage and Vanessa Hudgens, their characters are both convincing. John Cusack is also effective, creepy as a methodical murderer, while Radha Mitchell is wasted as Jacks wife. The atmospheric thriller is uneven; sometimes it is brilliant with realistic descriptions, sometimes it is just bad

All in all The Frozen Ground is a decent thriller that benefits from the effective acting from the cast, as well as the bleak locations.
good movie.  the only thing I have against is that I have a 32" monitor and the movie was about as big as my ipad.  expected it to fill the whole screen
This was an entertaining film with good performances. It's formulaic and the characters are not super well developed but it's good.

I enjoyed this very much. I have had a murder in my family and am always drawn to true crime; law and order dramas. I often find them emotionally insulting. But not this. The acting was good, Cusack made a believable, creepy dead-eyed psychotic. Cage was relentless which I like in a murder detective. The only movie I've seen so far about Alaska that was filmed in Alaska, so far as I could tell, much of it in Anchorage. Cage was convincing as the state Trooper and Cusack well cast as Robert Hansen -- the dark-rimmed glasses heightened the creep factor (See Hansen's wikipedia entry). Compelling story well told, though not entirely absent of a cliche scene or two, otherwise I'd give it a perfect score.

Drama? Sort of. Suspense? No. Action? No. Who-Done-it? No. Alaska scenery? Some but not enough. Engaging: very limited at best. Expected a crime drama where pieces had to be put together to identify bad guy. Well this not it. Only bright spot for me was leading female actor. Date movie? No. Viewing with spouse? Not bloody but bad language and some naked boobs. Guy only movie? No. Suggest you find something else to watch.

Dramatic, based on a true story movie, with very strong acting.
Not the usual role for Nic Cage, but he did a fine job and John Cusack was very convincing as the evil one.

Anchorage Police Department has a history neglect for young women who've been assaulted.  Based on historical facts, this is a moving and emotional ride to incarcerate a brutal murderer who preyed on young women and prostitutes in Alaska.
I was pleasantly surprised at how much my attention was captured by the story. Sometimes I fall asleep watching movies that are slow in parts or don't have much of a plot. No problem here!
I don't want to give away too much, this is about one of the most notorious serial killers in America's history, not just Alaska, totally worth your time.
This was a decent movie and they did a good job of portraying Anchorage in the 80's. John Cusack did a pretty good job with his character in the movie as did Nick Cage.

Having lived in Anchorage, Alaska where this story took place, during the time the investigation was active, and having personal knowledge of the investigators, since I was part of the law enforcement community at the time, I gave this movie an OK. The lack of communication between the Anchorage police and the State Troopers probably should have been more developed. This investigation took place before the age of computers and profiling, and that should have been more developed. but I was pleased to see that the great legwork  and some pure luck,  by the lead investigator resulted in the eventual arrest of Bob, the Baker, Hansen. Cage did do a fairly decent job of portraying the real life investigator who eventually solved the case.
Why do so many young women resort to prostitution and put themselves at risk of encountering psychopaths? "The Frozen Ground" tells the sometimes gruesome story of a trip through hell.

What's not to love about these two guys? Even if the movie is lame ---and this movie was anything but these two talents make up for any lack. The characters were real the working girls authentic(don't ask how I know) and the story as chilling as any around. don't miss this one.

Surprised Nicholas Cage took such a poor role. The story of this real-life serial killer is certainly interesting, but reading about it afterward on Wikipedia was more satisfying, since the script for the film is poorly written and filled with cliches. The acting is okay, but the script bogs the whole thing down, and given the Alaska setting, the cinematography was unimpressive (in contrast, say, to the beauty of Christopher Nolan's Insomnia).

The movie is great, told the story in a very compelling manner, very true to life (it is based on a true story).  No complaints there.

Expedited shipping (I paid $6 for it) didn't seem very quick.  The delay actually occurred before it left the origination site.  How long should it take to put a movie in an envelope and affix an address label?

Buy the movie - skip the expedited shipping and just wait.

I wasn't quite sure what to expect from the movie "The Frozen Ground." It's based on a true story and sometimes true life doesn't make an exciting movie.

Nicolas Cage and John Cusack were perfectly cast in the roles, respectively, of the Alaska State Trooper and the prolific serial killer he wanted to stop. Vanessa Hudgens was also excellent in the role of the prostitute that escaped the clutches of the killer.

I enjoyed seeing the scenery of Anchorage and the surrounding rugged wilderness, too. I've been up there before (near this same time period) and the movie brought back many memories.

NOTE: This movie does take the viewer through some of the seedier parts of Anchorage including strip clubs. There is nudity and strong language in the film.

The Frozen Ground is a 2013 American thriller film based on the true story of Alaskan detective Glenn Flothe (called Sgt. Jack Halcombe in the film). Halcombe sets out to end the murderous rampage of Robert Hansen, a serial killer who has silently stalked the streets of Anchorage for more than 13 years. As the bodies of Anchorage women start to add up, Sgt. Halcombe goes on a personal manhunt to find the killer. When 17-year-old Cindy Paulson escapes Hansen's unspeakable violence, she believes the law will take him down. Instead she finds herself, once again, fighting for her life. With his only ally, Cindy Paulson, Sergeant Halcombe is determined to bring the serial killer to justice.

This movie gives a gritty true to life display of the events that occurred in Alaska many years ago.  The movie is very well paced and does a good job at filling the movie with tension at a frenetic pace.

Cage is solid in the role as the detective and Cusask who I am not normally a fan of, does a great job as the mild mannered pathological serial killer.  Hudgens also does a great job at playing the prostitute who survives the killers attack.

Based on actual events, this is one movie that gets it right with displaying a gritty real story even displaying the real victims pictures in the movie and showing a tribute to them in the credits.

A worthwhile watch.

Cage and Cusak are perfect in these roles.

They took a true story and stayed with the truth of it and came out with a movie that keeps you involved through the whole thing. You know who the serial killer is from the beginning because it is a solved true crime. Robert  Hanson, a very bad man,  is portrayed as low key as he actually lived, splendidly by  John Cusak, older than his years in this one.  Nicholas Cage does a brilliant job as John Halcombe, the detective who runs Hanson down and puts him away. Vanessa Hudgens as Cindy, the unfortunate young prostitute leaves her innocence visible and vulnerable. 50 Cent, as her pimp, bad man, comes through for her just in time.  The rest of the cast are very good in their roles.  It's very cold in Alaska, and Robert Hanson is as cold bloodied as they come. Even colder than the winter, because they had to wait until summer to know the extent of the horror that Robert Hanson was.  Good movie! .

Including the "Nicolas Cage" haters out there, "The FROZEN GROUND" is a pairing of two highly underrated A-List Thespians... "John Cusack", the former darling of late adolescent Indy Films, has transitioned to a level that places him within the range of OSCAR Winners; "Al Pacino, and "Robin Williams", both of whom portrayed similar roles in an early 2000-decade "INSOMNIA". A difference being, "The FROZEN GROUND" is portraying a real-life story (though, fictionalized) of events that transpired in Alaska for several decades.

"Cusack" does a splendid job given how the Director chose to choreograph the film, and while "The FROZEN GROUND" doesn't capture the raw creepiness, anxiety, and maddening angst of "INSOMNIA", it is well worth viewing on many levels!  --GBJ

I watched this movie based on Judi O's review since she actually lives in Alaska and remembers when this occurred. THE FROZEN GROUND does a straightforwardly fine job of telling the story of 1980s Alaska serial killer Robert Hansen. It's easily the best based-upon-fact murder film to come along in some time. The keen use of settings brings about that crucial realism. Cusack and Cage both give impressive performances as Hansen himself and Alaska State Detective Jack Halcombe, a rather uncoppish cop (typical role for Cage). Vanessa Hudgens is spectacular as would-be victim Cindy Paulson; many of the other supporting cast also give excellent performances, particularly Curtis "50-Cent" Jackson as Paulson's sometime-pimp. THE FROZEN GROUND relates the police investigation with all its little holes, inconsistencies, and disagreements most convincingly. The film also gives a realistic--I assume, never having personally been there, of course--portrayal of the Anchorage underworld and red light district. Some gore and partial nudity: THE FROZEN GROUND is tasteful as possible without pulling any punches. Last but far from least, some of the small, apparently insignificant details--e.g., the moose in the alleyway--add oh-so-much in the way of subtle mood and symbolism.

This may have been hard to avoid, but it might worked better if the killer's identity was not made clear so early in the film and if more of the other  suspects had been brought into the picture. That way, there would have been some element of surprise for those not already familiar with this case, which isn't all that well-known. A bit more on Hansen's sickly unique M.O. might also have helped distinguish THE FROZEN GROUND. Finally, I wanted to see more on how exactly Paulson managed to escape Hansen, as well as why he managed to avoid arrest immediately after she did.

Let me first begin by saying that I am not a fan of Nicolas Cage, and there's maybe only one of two films that he's been a part of that I've actually enjoyed.  This doesn't mean I have some sort of vendetta against the man or his work - other than his style of acting not being my cup of tea.  For a man that was (at one point) on the verge of playing Superman, Cage sure has taken lead roles in some completely lackluster films - including Ghost Rider: Spirit of Vengeance, Drive Angry, and Stolen (with several more on top of those).  With that being said, the fact that it's been quite a while since Cage has been relevant has not bothered me in the slightest.  Truth be told, Cage will have to work extra hard to get back into Hollywood's spotlight, assuming he ever wants to be there.  In any event, he appears to be on the right track, starring in the new drama, The Frozen Ground.

Scott Walker makes his writing and directorial debut with The Frozen Ground, starring Nicolas Cage as Jack Halcombe - an Alaskan police sergeant that is assigned a case to bring a serial killer to justice.  For more than 15 years, Robert Hansen (John Cusack) has blended in with the community as an upstanding, respectable citizen - while secretly abducting, raping, and murdering young teenage girls.  His latest victim, a prostitute named Cindy Paulson (Vanessa Hudgens), is able to escape Hansen's clutches, but when she tells her story to the police, they don't believe her.  When Paulson's story is brought to Sgt. Halcombe's attention, he takes it upon himself to protect her while searching for enough evidence to put Hansen behind bars.  Curtis Jackson, Dean Norris, and Radha Mitchell also star in supporting roles.

Surprisingly, Nicolas Cage is on the top of his game in the role of Sgt. Halcombe.  When we first meet Halcombe, he's preparing to exit his job and start a new chapter in his life.  However, things change when he's put in charge of a series of murders that all resemble the same pattern:  the murder of young girls.  While Cage portrays the generic law enforcement lead - driven, ambitious, and won't settle for failure - he still manages to bring a realistic emotion to a character that rarely displays physical emotion.  This lead character, haunted by the death of his sister from an automobile accident, doesn't let death define him, yet this tragic incident provides another dimension to an otherwise predictable character.  All in all, this is probably Cage's most impressive role since World Trade Center.

While I'm mostly on the wrong side of the fence when it comes to Nicolas Cage, I would certainly call myself a fan of Cage's fellow co-star, John Cusack.  The careers of Cage and Cusack sort of mirror each other in terms of their popularity and status in the limelight.  Neither would be considered major stars, but both have a loyal following.  Both Cage and Cusack, previously collaborating on the 1997 summer blockbuster, Con Air, are back together and mesh together rather well in their reunion.  Cusack isn't exactly the most calculating villain in this flick, but he does an admirable jump - easily comparable to Robin Williams's villainous character in Insomnia.  From the very beginning, viewers are aware of who the bad guy is, and will go through the dramatic motions of various interactions in which the villain escapes being caught.  Unfortunately, Cusack's interaction with Cage is minimal and doesn't even occur until nearly three quarters of the way through the film - but the build-up is still worth the wait.

I'm on record of being against musicians taking their "talents" to acting, especially when it comes to singers like Britney Spears, Miley Cyrus, and Selena Gomez.  More often than not, their appearance in a film alone is enough to warrant a terrible review for a film.  However, in the case of Vanessa Hudgens - she has managed to work her way around joining the club of pre-mentioned singers turned "actresses."  Hudgens certainly stands out in that particular crowd, showing signs of potential in previous roles, like Spring Breakers and Sucker Punch (I said signs of potential).  She also shows signs of potential in various scenes in The Frozen Ground, mostly when she's drugged out or weeping in a police station - but the potential is there.  Surprisingly, she is given quite a bit of screen time, and doesn't completely bomb with it.  It's quite possible her future might be in film after all.  It might be low-budget, straight-to-video film, but that's film none-the-less.

More often than not, The Frozen Ground features an attention-sustaining pace - even though you can quickly predict the film's inevitable outcome.  The fact that this film is a true story, based on the murders committed by Robert Hansen between 1971 and 1983, at least provides a bit of history to go along with a foreseeable outcome.  There are shades of Christopher Nolan's Insomnia sprinkled all over this film, mostly since you'll be able to see the lives of two men taking different paths that will eventually intersect with one another.  The characters are written well, given average back stories, but really lack a big name presence that would have given this film much more attention than it did.  Like many flicks that only briefly land in theaters, The Frozen Ground went to on-demand and quickly to home video.  Was it worth a trip to the theater?  Probably not, unless you're a Cage or Cusack follower - but since you no longer need to leave your couch to watch this flick, it is certainly worth a view.

GRADE: B-
FNDNreview.com

This movie held up to Nicks' 'GOOD STUFF' record and I was pleased and excited to get it and view it and I plan on seeing it again--yep-it's just that good!

Not a 5 star movie, but definitely better than 3 star.  Thanks for the opportunity to use your service.  You guys destroy Comcast on reliability and quality.
The general plot of the movie was based on true facts. The lighting could use some work and refinement. Audio could be tweaked.

Great movie with Nicolas Cage as a US Trooper working in Alaska. It's been a while since I've seen Nick Cage is a movie with some meat in it.  Suspenseful true story about a serial killer who had been killing prostitutes and young girls in for many years before the authorities were able to piece together the evidence.  John Cusak plays the serial killer, and "Agent Schrader" i.e. Hank from "Breaking Bad" (Dean Norris) is also in this movie(and he's still live!). If you don't watch Breaking Bad, I apologize as you will have no idea what I'm talking about.
Anyway, very entertaining, it sucks you right in.
This film was very well acted and directed, especially for this genre. Great pacing throughout. Highly recommend it. Cage turns in a particular good performance.

My daughter told me when they were making this film up in Anchorage, Alaska.  She sent me the "Butcher Baker" book to read before the movie came out.  I'm a librarian, so I love to read the book before the movie comes just to see how much the producers and directors CUT OUT of the book to make the movie.  Well, this move is TRUE to the book.  Not much of the action, character building, or story line was left out.  A GREAT JOB was done by all.  The bakerman was a butcher!  Well worth being on the edge of your seat to see if they catch him or let him escape.
Enjoyed watching.  The movie was not as graphic as it could have been which I believe preserved Cusack's movie persona .  Would recommend to friends and family.

Good movie! Worth the money, it was a taut, engrossing psychological thriller. Though there are some actions scenes, it was more suspense than any kind of shoot 'em up/car chase action film. Well cast, Nicolas Cage did an excellent job and I think this is one of his best roles.

Effective use of cold, gray, snowy, wild Alaskan landscape, really set the mood for this film. If they ever want to do a horror film there, Alaska would be a good choice...sort of , at least in this film, had that creepy, gray, bleak, austere, X-file-ish vibe you get in so many horror/thriller films, but with the added elements of danger from the elements and just the utter isolation. People almost feared the landscape or lived in denial of its alien beauty, not speaking of it or even looking at it directly, living crowded together in squalid, run down, crime infested streets or in quaint suburbs, though just a few feet outside the door is the cold, driving snow, and the uncaring distant mountains.

The movie even had a few moments of beauty, which I thought elevated the film.

Set in the early 1980s, effective use also of period elements without being overwhelming, the focus of the movie, or in any way making me at least the viewer disrespect or underestimate the protagonists and antagonists (if one was encouraged or forced to laugh at some element of 1980s culture or technology, I think it would have undermined the film; that did not happen).

This movie was very intense about a serial killer and rapist. The acting was outstanding and i must say i was really drawn into the movie. It was excellent i would recommend this for a mature audience. Nicolas Cage, John Cusak and Vanessa Hudgens were all excellent it this! You won't be disappointed.
This movie is excellent, well done and great acting. Because its based on actual events it brings to life what really happened.

I enjoy movies based on true stories even though Hollywood seems to go way off track many times. According to some of the reviews this movie seems to stay on target.

Sad movie but I enjoyed watching it. (WARNING: Adult Survivors - this movie may sting a bit)

PS

A few day after seeing this movie I saw another movie called BREACH about Robert Hanssen; worst spy in US history. I did a search on him and coincidently his name is virtually the same as our boy Robert Hansen the serial killer, and came upon this great documentary that you guys may enjoy after seeing the movie. I know I did. [...]

This movie was a perfect blend of eclectic, spastic bad guy and unconventional copper good guy. Great interaction between Cusack and cage, they are both unique actors and made the dreary wintery setting even more gloomy.

I had been waiting to see this movie for over a year as I knew about the serial killer, Robert Hansen, that this movie is based on.  The performances were outstanding with Nic Cage (sad to say) being the least memorable with Vanessa Hudgens being the most outstanding.  I wish the movie focused more on Hansen than it did however all in all I feel the story they told flowed well.  My huge complaint with this movie is that it felt like a TV movie of the week and the scenes with Nic Cage and his wife weren't consistent.  First his wife hates that he cares and in their next scene she is madly in love with him because he does care.  Makes no sense.  The biggest impact this movie had on me was at the end, before the credits they list the names and photographs of the real victims of Hansen.

B00EQ1187S It took me approx. 35 minutes to rent this video and to finally be able to stream it to my blu-ray player. I was so frustrated by my inability to connect after I had paid for the rental that I called Amazon. I was told the hold time was 30 min PLUS!!! While I waited for the call back I continued to try and connect. After many, MANY tries I was successful. YIPPEEEEEE!!!! Fifteen minutes into the movie....THEN AMAZON CALLS .....AND PLACES ME ON HOLD!!! Of Course I HUNG UP!! We enjoyed the movie.....once we recovered from the trauma of the downloading nightmare.

It was just okay, one of those movies that is interesting enough while watching and then you pretty much forget about it after it's over.  The acting was pretty good in it and it was nice to see Nicolas Cage in a decent role. They kept it classy when it came to the re-enactment scenes but then spent a lot of the movie in the strip club showing everything and went overboard there.
I don't think it was worth the in-theaters price we paid to watch it, but it's worth the rental cost once it's out.
The story was awesome, but it is slow to get started. It can be hard to follow at first. Overall I would recommend this movie, but make sure you're awake.

I was really surprised how good this was.  Very tense and disturbing.  Nicholas Cage was was great and gave a low key intense performance.  The most amazing part was that the movie was based on a true story.

I lived in Alaska , I went to church with Bob and his wife Darla taught my kids in the Christian School , Bob was always a guest and speaker at our Father and Son dinners and would bring all his mounted heads and bear rugs and guns to display, Many of my friends hunted with him , I never did as I was always  hunting with my boys when they went . The movie is so right to the detail and a really true telling of the story of Bob Hansen , as in the movie ---just to talk and visit with him you would never think, or even believe , he could have done all those terrible things . And the actors did a super job , Cages best .

This is your basic "catch a rapist/killer" flick where they must find enough evidence to arrest the suspect.

Honestly, I like the movie. No big special effects. No car chases, no big shootouts, nothing like that.

I have not enjoyed many of Cage's movies in the last few years. In fact, I have even been avoiding his movies. I really like John Cusack movies. I feel both actors did a pretty good job. I found the movie interesting and it kept my attention to the end. For me, this is the best Cage movie I have seen in a long time.

Many people may find this movie too slow paced and lacking in the action department. Because it was based upon a true story, I did not mind. I am pleased they didn't try to Hollywood the story.

Simple, interesting. It is worth a $3.99 rental. $6.99 is a bit much for this movie but I have no regrets.

My rating. A 5 star movie is outstanding. 4 is great. 3 is pretty good, it was ok. So, a 3.

This film found it impossible to hold my interest after the first half hour, and it was a struggle up to then. I give it 3 instead of the 2 I wanted because Nicholas Cage deserves better. And that's the only reason.
So boring you will most likely shut it off early. There is nothing good about this dull flic. Save your time and money by watching paint dry.

Realistic story, and acting.  Elicits emotions in the viewer. Definitely worth watching and leaves you with that "I just saw a really good Movie feeling".

Nuff said.
Different role for the stars and they proved up to the task.  If you like mysteries, then you will enjoy.

True story done very well. Kept me on the edge of my seat the entire movie. Small spoiler - The story is of a serial killer (John Kusak)and the detective(Nick Cage)that knows he is guilty and is unable to find enough proof to arrest him. The killer continues to collect victims much to the frustration of the detectives. One woman victim was the only one to escape before he could kill her. It is her story as well. The movie is one large case of cat and mouse. Great performances by the lead characters.The Frozen Ground (Watch Now While It's in Theaters)
This was a good movie , don't know if I would watch it over and over but was good enough to watch

If I never see another "serial killer" film again, that will be too soon. Monsters of our modern age as opposed to -- I don't know -- Martians from the 1950s (Invaders from Mars) and Satanic cults from the 1960s (Rosemary's Baby), their obsessively documented exploits have eroded my faith in culture, if not humankind. Thanks to the Wonderful World of Internet, we can now read (and sometimes view) every detail of their heinous outbreaks, almost always perpetrated against women. Since the classic The Silence of the Lambs exploded across movie marquees in 1990, serial killers have become primetime fare sandwiched between beer commercials. We've been desensitized, or as Francois Truffaut once said, "It's impossible to make anti-war films because their energy and destruction make war look fun." With that said, the 2013 film "The Frozen Ground" is surprisingly good. Writer and director Scott Walker has crafted a thoughtful examination of the sad crimes of Alaskan serial killer Robert Hansen (Fair Game). An expert hunter with all the menacing presence of Uncle Rico, Hansen would kidnap women - usually prostitutes - release them into the wild and track them down. He murdered roughly 20 women before his arrest in the 1980s. Where "The Frozen Ground" succeeds is its unflinching look at Cindy Paulson, a victim who escaped the clutches of Hansen and told her story to disinterested authorities. In one of the great performances of the year, Vanessa Hudgens portrays Paulson as a haunted, street-wise loser. She's a runaway, scrapping a survivor's living as a part-time prostitute and full-time drug addict. She represents the high-risk lifestyle that serves as fodder for so many Hansen-like monsters. That she is turned into a sympathetic human being, undeserving of the cruelty dumped upon her by a variety of pimps and dealers, is one of the film's unexpected accomplishments. These female lost souls can be found in every city, chain smoking and fidgety, unjustly destined for ugly ends. "The Frozen Ground" has a better-than-deserved cast, including Nicolas Cage as local investigator Jack Halcombe and John Cusack as Hansen. Both actors, perhaps past their prime, having soared for decades with a variety of career peaks, serve up earnest portrayals. Cage's unorthodox intensity works well as he doggedly examines each crime scene, leading to the obligatory shot of him standing before victim photographs and stating, "What am I missing?!" After Hudgens's Paulson leaves the police station and disappears into the seedy side of Anchorage, Cage realizes she may be the key to cracking the case. These scenes are paralleled by Cusack's Hansen stalking another victim, including uncomfortable detail of his modus operandi. In reality, Hansen played it straight after Paulson's escape (she actually served as a technical adviser on this film), though the walls crumbled when police searched his home. Part of the suspense of "The Frozen Ground" hinges on authorities being unable to obtain a search warrant due to Hansen's positive reputation in the community, including having a wife and kids and being the proprietor of a popular bakery. Where "The Frozen Ground" also succeeds is its extraordinary on-location filming in Alaska. There is no doubt this film was entirely made within the state, with snow-covered streets and gray slush covering every frame. Skies are overcast, actor's faces are a variety shades of maroon and breath plumes from their shivering mouths. When Cage's Halcombe enters several strip clubs in search of Paulson, it's apparent these locales are real, with extras as authentic as a documentary. As the film ends, each Hansen victim is shown, an extended segment as we see photographs of numerous women, their names and the year they disappeared. It's a startling touch making us realize the overwhelming horror of this true story. Walker's film maintains emotional honesty by not only giving the victims faces, but in attempting to detail through Paulson the daily grind of outcast women living difficult lives. Authentic and gritty, "The Frozen Ground" is less about Hansen than the kind of women stalked by more than one monster within our society.

I found this a very tight and well done movie. The one flaw I would give this movie is to equate a vile serial killer with a DUI incident which led to loss of an innocent life. I don't blame a family member for feeling this way when they lose a loved one so senselessly, it's hard to control emotions. But an objective person must not bring emotion into this, there is no comparison between intentional murder and a horribly stupid accident.
When I watched this movie, I didn't know it was based on true happenings. I'm so glad the guy was caught! So sad about those that haven't been found.

I would describe this movie as a creepy thriller. Not a horror movie, but creepier than your normal thriller; not something you want to watch alone by yourself in the dark before bedtime, especially if you're a single woman. This movie does go to some disturbing places, so not a good family movie-night pick. I thought Nicolas Cage did a really good job and I was suprised by Vanessa Hudgens. Don't let her High School Musical past scare you away; her acting in "The Frozen Ground" proves she can be a serious actress. Overall, I thought this was a good movie. I recommended it to my friends, but gave them fair warning about the creepiness.
Remembered this story from when I was growing up. There are a lot of sick people out there.. I won't spoil the the story by expanding the thought.
nicolas cage always makes outstanding movies. a must have movie. will buy this one and watch over and over. good movie
I don't normally like movies based on actual events, but I enjoyed this one.  I happen to be a huge John Cusack fan and seeing him in this role was sobering.  Seeing him as a serial killer was scary.

I had hoped for just one thing:  that this movie would NOT glorify the persons involved, the crimes committed, nor the place where  they occurred. I wasn't disappointed, for it was not a "glorified" time in our city.  Rather, it was a lengthy span of too many months, seasoned with fairly regular, albeit minimal, media blurps that yet another girl had "gone missing."
  "The Frozen Ground" has captured the ambience of those sinister times when we learned to question who we knew and where and how they were spending their time away from the comforts of home and hearth. Amongst ourselves, we spoke in near whispers about common friends with quirky personalities, as we waited for the next "announcement" of a body found, or of a dancer who didn't show up for work.
  For all of its horrors, this is a grim and quiet film -- the story of a quiet investigation of a quiet businessman with a terrifying secret life. Alaska's magnificent wilderness plays an honest role, too:  cold, dark, menacing, where it's easy to disappear, where life is reduced to its lowest terms and survival will always reign supreme, where Hansen's prey didn't stand a chance.
  And it's accurate.  That really IS downtown Anchorage, and that IS the Knik River Bridge. It's the real Flattop Mountain in the foreground of the nighttime view of Anchorage.  And, yes, that IS the Alaska State Trooper building. There really WAS a "Wild Cherry" nightclub (and a couple of dozen more, just like it), the dancers were topless (and usually bottomless), and those ARE real photos of Hansen's victims hanging on the Troopers wall.
  More could have been told of Hansen's earlier life, but simply wasn't.  John Cusack is positively superb in the role, and Nicholas Cage is brilliant as the committed and caring cop who insists that all of the puzzle pieces are in plain view from the start.
  Five stars for this one, laced with a big dose Alaskan pride and prejudice.
Excellent acting; liked that there was no need for the graphic scenes as is the norm today.  The horrific ness of the crimes was enough.
I enjoyed the film. Cage was actually good and John Cusak was even better in his role. I'd watch it again.

Lackluster, by the numbers serial killer procedural. Cusack is apparently trying to break the "nice guy" mold with this and "The Paperboy" He was more successful in the latter for creepiness. Cage manages to loose his tic filled persona and zzzzzzzz is the result. Vanessa Hudgins gives it the ol' college try with some pretty weak material, better actress than I realized. Not much tension and no real surprises. Alaska setting manages to give it a pretty, somber setting. All in all, forgettable.

LOVED IT!  I did not know this was a true story until the end of the movie.  Great thriller.  John Cusack's best performance.  He gave me nightmares!  I don't know the girl (Vanessa Hudgens) from other movies but she was excellent.  A must see thriller, but soooo creepy.  I loved that they paid homage to the victims during the closing credits.

The acting is great.  I really enjoyed watching but sad that the story was true.
I recommend this movie because it is true.  I was really kept on the edge of my
seat all the way to the end
Very good thriller and John Cusack and Nicolas Cage couldn't be better. It's base on real events so it's also very moving.

As I understand it, this is a first-time writer/director who put together a very nicely done film.  Good characters, and nice focus away from the criminal onto the relationship between the victim and the State Trooper who had to gain her trust.  Couple niggling points on the speed with which the trooper's wife came around to him staying with the force (needed one more conversation in there) and the slow opening pacing, which would have been better served by a video flashback sequence to what happened to the victim and how she got away.  But really a well-done film.

Good acting all around, especially the three leads. Suspense and tension held for what seemed like an impossible amount of time (my wife was digging her nails into me, so I was counting the seconds ticking by).

I was a newsman in Anchorage when these crimes, and this serial killer were in the news, and the suspense in the movie matched the tension all of Anchorage felt.

I especially appreciated director Scott Walker's tight control that helped make this a solid thriller plot that came in at just 1 hour, 45 minutes. And it was great to see Anchorage as a location for a decent movie. Loved the early scene where the helicopter comes up over snow-laden trees to see the lights of Anchorage spread out in the darkness. (I think they made that shot from Fire Island.)
One of the best movies , I have seen in years . Two thumbs up.  We need more new movies, not remakes of old ones.  The cast were  excellent.  yes I would see it again.
Great story of the Butcher Baker of Alaska. I was not aware of the killings until this movie so had to google it and read more.
The movie has: an interesting story, interesting characters, good actors, and action that is believable.  As Budd Boetticher would say "a man can do that".

The frozen ground is a true story about the evil serial killer Bob Hanson.  He hunted down probably more than 24 women.  But he only admitted to 17 victims. Nicolas Cage puts in one of his best performances as the detective who helped bring him to justice. The mean streets of the early 1980's downtown Anchorage ALaska is well depicted here. Alaska had a horrible crime rate during the pipeline era and it still has problems.  John Cusack is outstanding as the serial killer hanson in this one. And the rest of the cast does  a fine job in this one as well.  The film is often at night and dark, and it is dark in Anchorage  in the fall in Anchorage.  This seems to have been filmed in Anchorage and that's a plus for realism as well. I don't understand why anyone but a videogame idiot would say this is boring , because there isn't explosions and violence?  and the detective is working
 against time to stop the killer or he may get away for good. And the young prostitute runaway is being hunted by both  Hanson and a hired killer.  Which leads to the death of a pimp as well. It was very suspenseful and everyone involved should be proud of this movie.  This looks good in HD but it's a dark movie and it's shot in a dark place.

This film takes place in cold conservative Alaska where there is no crime and everyone has a job because they all own guns...and something about the oil companies. This production is based on the true story of serial killer and rapist Robert Hansen played far too convincingly by John Cusack. After prostitute Cindy Paulson (Vanessa Hudgens) escapes from Hansen, the cases of unsolved crimes are given to Jack Holcolme (Nicolas Cage) the only cop in America who has trouble getting a warrant.

This is not a who-dun-it, but rather the story leading up to the arrest of Robert Hansen. It gives you glimpses of Anchorage's red light district filled with pimps, prostitutes, strippers, drug dealers, and a moose. This is a gritty tale. 5 stars for those who enjoy true crime stories.

Parental Guide: F-bombs, stripper nudity. The film deals with rape, but does not show it.  Limited amounts of blood, relatively tame on the graphics. It is not an exploitation style film.
Suspense was palpable @ times. Very good movie. If you like serial killer movies watch this movie, no disappointment here.

This had the potential to be a great movie but suffered from poor direction and cheaply done shooting and drab locations, It was as if the film crew just flew into Alaska and pulled out their equipment and started to film and left the next day.  I know it's suppose to be based on the seedy parts of Anchorage but with all the beautiful scenery available in Alaska they could have made use of it or waited until summer to shoot this film, what a waste of a great all star cast.  By the way Nicolas Cage was really outstanding playing the part of the lead Alaskan State Trooper who's persistence lead to the arrest of the killer and John Cusack who played the role of the serial killer was also outstanding playing his part,  All in all its a good movie and keeps you on the edge of your seat.
This movie was good but not great.  Based on a true story, but, it was a little slow in some spots.  The end is the most important part.

I can't believe that I might really allow Nicolas Cage to get a thumbs up?!?!?! What is wrong with me? I think he actually showed a different kind of depth to his acting and it is believable. I could actually relate to his character and his characters own personal demons that are propelling him along in the story. Is it an Oscar worthy performance?.... Hell no. But, it is compelling and I really have a different kind of perspective on Nic Cage and his acting chops. By the way.... Super creepy performance by John Cusack. Good movie.

This was a great movie!  I feel like this was a really well done movie.  I feel like it was tactfully well done, and showed a great respect to the victims and families who were impacted by this horrific person.  I also really appreciated how well, and true, they depicted Anchorage.  Having lived there for a number of years, I can honestly say, it is not all glamorous and pretty like the rest of the state and I think Scott Walker did a great job capturing this.  I've read some reviewers complain how the plot was too predictable, well, let me ask you this, did you hate the Titanic too because you had a 'hunch' it was going to hit an ice burg?

"He stalks them like his next trophy animal. He rapes them and he kills them and he's probably doing it right now. We don't have a few days." Jack Halcombe (Cage) is an Alaskan trooper a few weeks from retirement. When a young woman begins to describe the kidnapping and rape she endured at the hands a a deranged madman (Cusack) Jack wants to help. When he finds out this isn't the first time this has happened we wants nothing more then to bring him to justice. This is a true story. Many of you know of my disdain for Nicolas Cage. I don't think he's a good actor at all and his presence alone can make me think twice about watching a movie. All that said he really didn't bug me in this. Now that that's out of the way...after reading the description about this movie I was expecting something along the lines of Insomnia. I guess because it was about a serial killer in Alaska. Either way this was a good movie but started off really slow and a little boring and I found it hard to get into through out. The end did get better and I was glad I finished but this really is nothing special. A decent made-for-TV type movie that only seems better due to the cast. Overall, a very unexciting serial killer movie that would have been relegated to TV if not for Cage and Cusack. I give it a B-.

Nick Cage's best work yet and although I hate seeing John Cusack as a serial killer , he sure was believable as one. Excellent job showing the dedication to the many victims and their identities after the movie.

I enjoyed this movie mostly because I am from Alaska and is always neat to watch a movie about the history from my home state, Nicholas Cage did a great job in this movie and John Cusak was awesome - he scared me he played such a great creepy guy.  This movie is a definite 'BUY'.
Kept our interest throughout the whole movie.  It is a true story and it gives the pictures of real victims.

I admit it. I was duped into watching this film by the previous reviews, who claimed this was a "suspenseful" movie.

Not even close.  Predictable from the very beginning, this is at best a good attempt to copy the "Nordic noir" style of much, much better films and TV series coming out of Scandinavia and being copied (well) by BBC and AMC (Seen "The Killing" yet?  That show is lightyears ahead of this sad film).

Save your money.  Watch this when it's free on Netflix - because it will be soon.

For the life of me I don't know why this film did not have major release. It captures Alaska and it captured the twists and turns of this case that frightened us throughout this time period. We knew there was a killer out there, but who? I was living in the bush and received my newspapers to find yet another body had been discovered. I am a hunter and was highly disturbed when I found out what Hanson had done. I am so glad to see a film of this quality has been made on this story.

 The acting in this is superb. I knew Cage would pull it off but darling Cusack of Llyod Dobbler, SAY ANYTHING fame? One look at his face in those glasses and I was owned by his portrayal of Robert Hanson, the Butcher/Baker Killer. HE frightened me from the get-- he WAS Robert Hansen. The music is perfect, so much so that you may miss some of it as ambiance when you are pulled into the gray days of winter and the sordidness of downtown Anchorage that is very, very real; much like many other cities that offer no solution for human degradation.  The story is so real, only someone who has studied the case can know exactly what is fiction. Every element fits so well together. It is amazing to look back and see how a crime like this was solved. Although the film shows Anchorage Police Department (APD) as being sexist and culturally biased, and unwilling to take the case which I am not sure is true-- with the State Troopers as being the persistent trackers of this case, the blame has a universal appeal in that it has been this very attitude of dismissing the deaths of social underworld inhabitants that has allowed killers to go undetected. And it is an attitude worth looking at. Many people responded in the newspaper comments feeling that these deaths were the work of someone just "taking out the trash," one reason I think Hanson thought he would get away with it, and he might have had it not been for criminal justice persistence. We know so much more about criminal profiling now and have so many more tools for investigation and crime solving. Police Departments are so much more advanced now.

This story was woven so well and I am thankful it was written, bringing attention to how stressful violence can make life for the whole community. As a society we have now totally re-thought the nature of a murderous criminal; not so easily defined and this case contributed to that knowledge. We now know pillars of the community can be violent criminals. Robert Hanson proved that and Cusack nailed it to the screen. Brilliant film.
This is a fantastic movie.  Intense and on your seat exciting from beginning to end.  Cage and Cusack are brillian and I am looking forward to the day when I own it.

As an Alaskan who remembers the case in the late 70's and 80's, I was excited to find out that they were making the movie and filming it in Anchorage.  I loved the way Hollywood tried to capture the look of Anchorage during that time.  I enjoyed the movie and give kudoss to Nic Cage, John Cusack, and Vanessa Hudgens.  The movie will find a place in the hearts of Alaskans (we are always excited when Hollywood gets it partially correct on screen).  The movie was not the greatest, but it was entertaining.  it could have dipped more into the life and history of Hansen so the audience could understand the madness behind the man.  John Cusack captured Hansen's creepiness. Just walking into Hansen's Bakery in Anchorage and seeing him in the store behind the counter gave me the creeps back then. You wanted to get your items and get out there quickly. John did a great job with his portrayal of Hansen.

The movie is about the capture of Robert Hansen, a baker in Anchorage, Alaska in the 70's and early 80's who committed a series of murders against young women.  He has also an avid hunter. He picked up, raped, and murdered prostitutes in Anchorage.  He would then chain them up, torture them in his basement, and then fly them out in his plane, murder like a hunter trying to hunt prey, and bury them in remote hunting areas in Alaska.  The story focuses on the investigation of the Alaska State Troopers to bring about a case with evidence against Hansen.  He had one surviving victim (Vanessa Hudgen's character) who was lucky to escape and help the Trooper convict Hansen.

It was a good movie, not a great one.  It is one that I would recommend to any Alaska or non-Alaskan.
Very good movie
One of the best Nicholas Cage movies ever. John Cusack was amazing as well. Very heart wrenching movie. Wow!

I've read a number of true crime books, but haven't delved too much into movies.  I was actually steered towards this one - which I'd never heard of - by a review on another movie, so three cheers to Amazon reviewers for helpful recommendations!

The movie intrigued me for a number of reasons - true crime, drama, and John Cusack playing a character other than, well, John Cusack.  Don't get me wrong, I love the heck out of a socially awkward, passionate about music, good looking & articulate guy as much as everyone, but I was interested in seeing him portray a different sort of character.  He does so well, the average guy next door with twisted desires and dark secrets, pushed to the edge of discovery by Nicholas Cage, playing - well, not Nicholas Cage.  You know, the somewhat over the top slightly kooky guy?  Not this time.  It's a nice role reversal on the good guy/bad guy dynamic that they had in Con Air (which I'll need to watch again soon) with both parts played quite convincingly and realistically.

The theme and the setting of the movie is dark, a pallor cast over it from early on that makes you want to see if your monitor or TV has changed settings while you weren't paying attention.  The action mainly comes in the form of suspense, with some difficult scenes and little humor to break the mood, or even worse, mock the truth behind the tale.

Given that this is based on a true story, I felt it was written, scripted, and acted out with respect for what happened, and for the victims and their families.  Demons do live among us, sometimes frighteningly close, with angels as passionate about protecting people as the demons are about hurting them.

I watched this because it had "based on actual events" attached to it and I am a sucker for anything based on a true story. I did not know the background of the man being investigated or the heinous nature of his crimes. Thankfully, these were not glorified in this movie in any way. This movie does a great job focusing on the victim that survived and is now thriving in her life. It also showcases the tenacity of one law enforcement officer who believed a story told by a girl who had a less that reputable lifestyle. He heard her truth and her pain and he followed through with seeing that her story was investigated. John Cusack's performance is noteworthy. He is cold and ruthless and he is portraying a true human monster in this film. This isn't really an edge of your seat type of film, but it will keep you watching until the end.

One of the best true stories I have seen.  If you like an on the edge of your seat serial killer movie this is for you!  CAGE did a performance that was Oscar worthy.  The film was based very closely on the facts.  This is a true winner.
Very good movie. It is scary to know it was based on true events.
I have seen a documentary of this case.  The movie embellishes a little, but is a pretty accurate account of some dedicated officers who refused to be cowed by the political hacks in the DA office.

Excellent suspense movie. As always Nicolas Cage made a fantastic performance which made of this movie a great/so real movie. Anyway it is a true story movie.  I felt Nicolas Cage passion in his roll, the desperation to stop the killer. I suffered during an hour. It got me very into it. Very well done. I wonder why we don't have more sargeants/officers like him in the department of investigation.

Five stars for just making a movie like this based on real life and some stories that would otherwise never be brought to life on screen. Especially good acting by Nicholas Cage and good, overall supporting acting. The only downside was casting John Cusack in the "villain's" role; did not portray as much of an ominous feel compared to what the actual person (Robert Hansen) being depicted may have been like.
